story:
Short Summary

It began when I realized I had been duped by the Russian Intelligence Agency.

I’d been following an account called "Blacktivist" on Facebook throughout the 2016 election year. Its posts were of the “feel-good” variety, things of cultural interest to African-Americans: elementary school kids reciting heroes of black history; or an actor describing the problem of colorism and casting in Hollywood. Turns out, I was following a fake account created by Russians intended to suppress the vote of African Americans by undermining our trust in American institutions. If I, a journalist with 30 years' experience, could be fooled by a fake account, how many others were? And how could we, the people, begin a conversation to counter the effect of social media weaponized as a tool of voter suppression?  

"Casting the Vote: A Call to a Count" is a collaboration between director Charlotte Brathwaite, a 2019 Creative Capital Awardee; dramaturg Sunder Ganglani, writer Janani Balasubramanian and musician Justin Hicks.  We are working on a new way to bring journalism to an audience and to engage them in the issues facing our democracy.  We've gathered a formidable group of theatre artists, young performers, chefs, and community organizers to bring my journalistic research on voter suppression to diverse audiences in new ways, and get them seriously engaged in the urgent issues haunting the very core of our democracy. This FREE evening, 7p October 16 at La Mama Experimental Theater is a dinner, a party, a call to action, a gathering, a survival guide for troubling times. There's documentary, live music, performance, food; and most of all, there's deep and pluralistic conversation. Together, we'll examine historical and contemporary voter suppression and chew on the upcoming 2020 census--all in an effort to understand 'who counts' in America, and how we might come to count on one another in the struggle for democracy, justice, and a more perfect union.

The performance was workshopped at MIT last Spring, with support from the Brown Institute for Media Innovation at Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Our perks are designed to make you a part of our performance, and to provide you with a seat at our table!
  • Director Charlotte Brathwaite and I are working on a new way to bring journalism to an audience: through performance and discussion. We're both award-winning artists looking to take our work to a different level, and to engage audiences in defining what's possible.
  • .We believe democracy is created person to person, moment to moment. In "Casting the Vote" we gather those people and we create those moments. Through live performance, we can bring investigative journalism to life. Voter suppression, redistricting, and census-taking can seem statistical, abstract, and - let's face it - boring.  We use strategies of live art to make these issues as intimate and personal as they truly are
  • We have been generously funded by the Brown Institute, but have a $10K gap we need to fill in order to showcase this performance  - a ONE NIGHT ONLY event October 16.  We want to use this performance to get us to the next level - funding for a series of dinners around the country during the 2020 election year.

The Impact

  • You get to help us develop and extend a discussion about our relationship to democracy.
  • A part of your donations will go towards paying our troupe, the Impact Repertory Theater, which is a group of young performers using theater to develop leadership skills and political awareness.  We need to hire a chef and pay for music and lighting. If we achieve our funding goal, we'll be able to pay ourselves for our time and archive the performance as part of a possible interactive web documentary.

Risks & Challenges

We only have a month, and we're both busy AF.  We need you to help us get the word out and give what you can.  Our networks ensure our success - we're rich in social capital. Join us!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Even if you can't contribute, please help share the word about this campaign and our work!

story:
Help us turn ETC. from a dream to reality

We are so excited to announce the launch of a new arts collective, Eccentric Theater Company (ETC.) We currently have a show in FringeNYC this month, and just began rehearsals on Doubt, A Parable - taking place at St. Paul's in Teaneck this September.

We are reaching out to our friends and family to try and raise money to make these shows, and our future shows, the best they can possibly be.

About ETC.

Eccentric Theater Company (ETC.) is a collection of artists dedicated to pushing the boundaries of a standard theater company. We believe that the lines between different facets of art are currently too rigid, and we aspire to create a space where an audience member can experience a play, a jazz club, an art gallery, and sometimes all three at the same time!

Started by a mother and daughter duo, ETC. combines the fast-paced nature of professional artistic work with the warm environment of community theater to produce skillful art created with love. We want you to feel at home every time you come and join us, whether you are coming to a rehearsal, attending a performance, or simply emailing us ideas for a future project.

ETC. aims to bridge the gap between New York City and New Jersey artists. We plan to use spaces throughout New York City and northern New Jersey that best fit the feel of each piece of art we create. We hope you will follow us on the journey of discovering new forums of art while uncovering new spaces.

ETC. not only stands for Eccentric Theater Company, but also for etcetera. There are no limits to what etcetera can stand for, and there are no limits to the types of art we hope to produce. If you can create it, we want to showcase it.

What we need:

As an entirely new performance company, we have many cost associated with putting on each production:

  • The obvious production cost (set pieces, props, lighting design, space rentals, costumes, etc.)
  • We hope to set a precedent of paying all of our cast and crew for their efforts. Yes, this means we are paying our actors for each show they are in. Though we cannot promise any particular amount at this time, we hope to raise enough money to properly compensate our performers for their hard work.
  • Purchasing insurance so that our cast, crew, and audience members are fully safe at each rehearsal and performance.

In addition, The more money we are able to raise now, the more ambitious productions we can plan for the future.

About Doubt, A Parable

In this brilliant and powerful drama, Sister Aloysius, a Bronx school principal, takes matters into her own hands when she suspects the young Father Flynn of improper relations with one of the male students.

Starring Shernetta Harris, Lou Ann Salkin, Veronica Shea, and James Walsh. 

Other Ways You Can Help

ETC has the goal of creating a home away from home for all artists and art-lovers. In addition to monetary support, there are so many ways for you to get involved in our inaugural season!

  • Come and audition for the company! We will be holding auditions for our upcoming shows soon, and more information can be found on our website!
  • Have a business/technical skill? We want you to share it with us! Simply email us at eccentrictheatercompany@gmail.com to join team!
  • Share us with your friends! Getting the word out about such a new company is vital. Every like, tweet, and share truly mean so much to us.

story:
THE MISSION

The Artizen Company is a film and theater company that specialzes in theatrical presentations with audience participation and interaction. We are creating an immersive experience called Silent Encounters, loosely based on the beloved and championed debut novel The Heart Is A Lonely Hunter by Carson McCullers, to explore human connection, communication, and our ability to rise to the challenges life presents, with a souther gothic sensability. 

We are excited to work with our two lead actors, Ellen Rice (left) and Candace Myers (right) - who are deaf, and to announce their work on stage during September 2015, National Deaf Awareness Month.  We were not aware at the inception of this project that it is rare to have deaf actors play deaf roles. The Artizen Company never thought to have hearing actors perform in these roles until we began our search and discovered that deaf actors were difficult to find. However, we are overjoyed to have found Mrs. Rice and Mrs. Myers. They have been instrumental in helping The Artizen Company gain a better understanding of Deaf culture.

Like in the novel, their characters, Antonapoula and Joan Singer, eat, drink, sleep, and receive visitors. They do not speak; Singer knows sign language, while Ant does not. They and their visitors must find a way to effectively communicate while all around they’ll be presented with an endless stream of media showing failing communication. Will our true human condition be evident with these two offerings juxtaposed? Can we gain some deeper insight, or grow from the experience? These are just a few of the conversations our production of Silent Encounters will spark.

THE TARGET

Help The Artizen Company fully realize this production of Silent Encounters. The production is set to open October 1, 2015 and run through October 4, 2015 as a part of the Curious Encounters festival at 7 Stages theater in Atlanta, GA. The cast and crew are assembled and the times are set.

We need funds for production costs and to compensate all artists involved. We have a budget of $7000, and are asking all theater lovers and newcomers, the Deaf and Hard of Hearing Community and supports to sponsor us with a donation. Please contribute to this potentially life-changing experience for audiences and the production crew alike. Eyedrum Art and Music Gallery of Atlanta, GA is our non-profit arts organization fiscal sponsor for tax-exempt donations. Thank you for your much needed and valued support. 

Here is a breakdown of our remaining expenses:

  • Design Elements: Costumes, Sound, Sets & Props: Need - $2,100 (30%)
  • Artists & Staff Compensation: Need - $3,850 (55%)
  • Supplies, gifts, nd fees: Need - $1050 (15%)
We appreciate every single donation, from $1 to $7000, and thank you for supporting diversity on the stage! We have some very interesting perks for supporting this special project and letting your voice be heard. Take a look!

  


  


Oh, listen no worries! Even if we don't meet our full $7000 goal. The show will go on and each and every dime will be spent on the production and the artists involved.

The Optics

The goal of this production is to change the world, one visitor at a time, by exploring how we connect and communicate. The dichotomy of our complex language is at the heart of this experiment: We have a plethora of words, yet these very words allow for deceit and confusion. We challenge our performers and our audience to find a deeper, truer way to communicate feelings, desires, and ideas by allowing only nonverbal communication.  The Artizen Company strives to make a positive impact on our community with every project, and Silent Encounters is no different. We are using our immersive and interactive style to help break down barriers and effect change. 

With have had great success with our previous immersive productions. Audience were effected in way we couldn't even imagine. When a person is asked to act and are given an opprotunity to step-up to save a life, assist in the a birth, determine the fate of another, or simple dance lives change and life long connections are made. This is what The Artizen Company's immersive theater accomplishes.

Risks & Challenges

The major risk we face with this production is people just not connecting with our efforts. The whole purpose of this project is to connect human beings to other human beigns without words. If this is not an expereience people will always carry with them we missed the mark.

However, we have a fluid and improvization methond of preparaion. During our workshops we develop skills to engage the audience and to adjust and refine as the evening progresses.  You could even say Silent Encounters is a living breathing show.

The Other Ways You Can Join the Team

Please share our campaign with friends, family, theater lovers, newbees, and the Deaf and Hard-of hearing communities. Send a personal note to ask others to help out! Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the workd and help make this work thrive! Be apart of the team.

                              

      Ellen Rice                   Candace Myers                        Jeffery Biggers

               

      Aimee McCoy                          Tae Eady

  • We have opportunities for ushers at each performance or perhaps you're handy with power tools or have access to low-cost printing . . . please contact us if you want to get involved!
  • Spread the word - You can do this right from home!
  • Use the share tools below . . . the more this crowdfunding drive goes viral, the more chance we have of sharing the world premiere of SILENT  ENCOUTERS with the widest audience possible!

Thank you from the collaborative team of SILENT ENCOUTERS and all of us at THE ARTIZEN COMPANY! 

The Artizen Company is a sponsored project of Eyedrum Art and Music Gallery, a non-profit arts organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of The Artizen Company must be made payable to Eyedrum Art and Music Gallery only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Thank you for getting interactive with us!

story:
Short Summary

Life in Colour is an original musical by TaTe (Tokyo Artistic Theatre Ensemble). 
It tells the story of a man who spends his life in the doldrums of bureaucracy. When he is diagnosed with a terminal illness, he realizes he hasn't lived at all. A wild night on the town and a stripper with a heart of gold inspire him to use the time he has left to make his mark on the world. 
Life in Colour inspires us all to make the most of every day and live passionately, not just live to work.
TaTe provides a way for artists, playwrights and musicians to stage their works. We produce works in English, Japanese and a mix of the two languages/cultures. 
The show will go on -- in late 2016!

What We Need & What You Get

We need $15,000 to make this a reality. That goes for theatre rental, sets, props, costumes, makeup, technical equipment as well as compensation for cast, crew, designers.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this with everyone you know! Support other TaTe projects!

story:
Montclair Shakespeare Series

The Montclair Shakespeare Series is a free Shakespeare concert reading series designed to bring professional caliber classical theatre to the Montclair community. Each reading is accompanied by live, original music. The program kicked off in May 2015 with a one-night-only staged reading of Twelfth Night accompanied by live acoustic music at the Montclair Women's Club, followed by A Midsummer Night's Dream and As You Like It, performed outdoors at the Van Vleck House & Gardens. Each reading is held in a historic, site specific venue in Montclair, and is meant to be kept "no frills," hearkening back to the simplest form of spoken storytelling. Both local artists and established AEA professionals from NYC have volunteered their time to perform. This is celebration of Shakespeare's work and the cultural community of Montclair, which has always had an appreciation for the arts, but currently has little professional theatre available. Readings are free and open to the public, as it is our mission to make live performance of these plays available to everyone!

The series follows a somewhat similar format to that of Project Shaw, a popular staged reading series based in NYC (http://gingoldgroup.com/) but will focus on the work of William Shakespeare.

In a concert-style staged reading, plays are read by the actors with the script in hand with very limited staging. The emphasis is on the language and on the actors' ability to bring the characters to life without costumes, sets, or movement.

Our next reading is The Tempest, scheduled for September 2015.


How You Can Help

Donations/Funding  help us secure a suitable venue for the series for this season and beyond. We are happy to have forged partnerships with the Van Vleck House & Gardens, and other spaces, but affordable space can be hard to come by, and every little bit helps! Offers for use of a venue for performance or rehearsal by businesses or individuals are also greatly appreciated as we search for a permanent home.

Donations will also contribute toward the travel stipends required for Actors' Equity Association members coming to Montclair from NYC to perform. This ensures that we can have the highest caliber professional talent involved in this project, which is what sets us apart from local and community productions. 

Our goal is to continue this reading series beyond 2015, and potentially register as a non profit organization in the future. In doing so, we can expand our programming and outreach. Your donations will help us as we launch ourselves and our upcoming programs.


Our Goals and Mission

We are passionate about bringing these classic plays to life in their simplest form,  stripped down to their basic truth. Storytelling through poetic language alone has become a thing of the past, and we hope to change that. As a culture, we have a lot to learn about how to really listen.

We want to make performances free and available to everyone in the Montclair community. We are looking forward to forging ahead with education programs and other community engagement opportunities, to involve our professional actors with the community and with students. It is our hope that the company can grow and find a permanent home here in Montclair, and can expand beyond the works of Shakespeare.

Risks & Challenges

Launching a theatre project is an extremely difficult task, and many companies have struggled to stay afloat in Montclair due to high venue rents and expenses. It is our goal to finally find a way bring theatre to this community at a low cost, but in the past we have only just barely broke even, as we have not wanted to compromise our integrity by charging admission.

Other Ways You Can Help

We always need volunteers to help run our box office, coordinate actor transportation, provide marketing/promotional support, and assisting in rehearsals. These gestures go a long way and have made our events possible!

Also, referrals or offers for use of a venue/space for rehearsal and performance are just as good as a donation.

or movement. 
Our next reading is The Tempest, scheduled for September 2015. 

  How You Can Help

Donations/Funding  help us secure a suitable venue for the series for this season and beyond. We are happy to have forged partnerships with the Van Vleck House & Gardens, and other spaces, but affordable space can be hard to come by, and every little bit helps! Offers for use of a venue for performance or rehearsal by businesses or individuals are also greatly appreciated as we search for a permanent home. 
Donations
 will also contribute toward the travel stipends required for Actors' 
Equity Association members coming to Montclair from NYC to perform. This
 ensures that we can have the highest caliber professional talent 
involved in this project, which is what sets us apart from local and community productions.  
Our goal is to continue this reading 
series beyond 2015, and potentially register as a non profit organization in the 
future. In doing so, we can expand our programming and outreach. Your 
donations will help us as we launch ourselves and our upcoming programs. 

  Our Goals and Mission
We are passionate about bringing these classic plays to life in their simplest form,  stripped down to their basic truth. Storytelling through poetic language alone has become a thing of the past, and we hope to change that. As a culture, we have a lot to learn about how to really listen. We want to make performances free and available to everyone in the Montclair community. We are looking forward to forging ahead with education programs and other community engagement opportunities, to involve our professional actors with the community and with students. It is our hope that the company can grow and find a permanent home here in Montclair, and can expand beyond the works of Shakespeare. 
  Risks & ChallengesLaunching a theatre project is an extremely difficult task, and many 
companies have struggled to stay afloat in Montclair due to high venue 
rents and expenses. It is our goal to finally find a way bring theatre 
to this community at a low cost, but in the past we have only just barely broke even, as we have not wanted to compromise our integrity by charging admission. 
  Other Ways You Can Help
We always need volunteers to help run our box office, coordinate actor transportation, provide marketing/promotional support, and assisting in rehearsals. These gestures go a long way and have made our events possible!
Also, referrals or offers for use of a venue/space for rehearsal and performance are just as good as a donation.

story:
LSNelson Productions, in association with Craig Baruk and Ryan Tramont, presents the world premier of Sweet Texas Reckoning, by Traci Godfrey, a new play about love, family, secrets revealed… and coming home to Sealy, Texas.  Directed by Geoffrey Cantor and featuring Laurence Olivier Award Winner, Drama Desk Award Winner, and Tony Nominee, Jane Summerhayes; Film and TV Veteran Anne Richardson; Robbie Award and California Theatre Award Winner Michelle Hurd; and Commercial and Voice-Over Veteran, Robb Pruitt.  With Shaun Bennett Fauntleroy, Cover; Rebecca Yarsin, Stage Manager; Zach Pizza, Lighting; Michael Lee Stever, Sound; and featuring the music of the David Wax Museum

We are all very excited to bring Traci Godfrey’s extraordinary new play Sweet Texas Reckoning to the stage for the first time.  One of the goals of this Thespis Festival presentation is to test the waters and develop the material in preparation for a 2016 Off Broadway Run!  Be a part of this exciting adventure from the earliest stage.  Please support us with your gift in any amount; no gift is too small (or too large!) Your gift of $25 will provide us with an hour of rehearsal in a studio, $50 will costume an actor, $100 will print programs, $250 will build a major part of the set.  Whatever you are able to give will be greatly appreciated, and whether you contribute $5, $50, or $500, your gift will be acknowledged in our program and on our Fackbook Page.  Please take a moment to “Click & Give”!

From all of us at Sweet Texas Reckoning... THANK YOU!

See you at the theatre ~ Linda S. Nelson & The Texas Team!

Special thanks to Michael Snyder for Posters; Geoffrey Cantor for Artwork; and K2 Enterprises, Inc. for “Perk” Merchandise


Please Join Us at The Thespis Festival

at Hudson Guild Theatre

Friday, September 25th @ 6:15PM

Sunday, September 27th @ 8:30PM

for tickets & information go to

http://thespisnytheaterfestival.com/sweettexasreckoning/

story:
Contribute to an important piece of theater that is socially-relevant, wonderfully reviewed, powerful and entertaining!

About Our Journey

Death of the Persian Prince premiered at the NYC Midtown International Theater Festival to sold out audiences in July, 2015. We received phenomenal reviews as well as features in the Advocate Magazine, India.com, Next Magazine, Frock Magazine, ReviewFix.com, and TheatreReviewsltd.com. Immediately after the premiere we were invited to participate in the South Asian International Performing Arts Festival, where we were honored with the festival's Best Play Award. The show was then invited for a limited Off Off-Broadway run at DMAC-Duo Theater in NYC, where it was enthusiastically received by audiences, and it became clear that a longer run Off-Broadway was our next step.
LISTEN TO THE PODCAST FROM LOCALTHEATERNY.COM >>

What We Need

$10,000. We are asking for seed money to help continue our proven track record. We will be able to expand our staff, reserve theater space and other pre-production steps with this amount.

Why You Should Contribute 

“Sexual reassignment surgery is legal in Iran; however, homosexuality is forbidden and in most cases for males, punishable by death,” according to a 2014 report by the BBC. “There is no reliable information on the number of gender reassignment operations carried out in Iran. But one doctor from an Iranian hospital told the BBC that he alone carries out more than 200 such operations every year.”

Death of the Persian Prince sheds light on this little-known topic by telling a very human story; this isn't a political issue-oriented play, but rather a powerful and emotional story of the human spirit. Howard Miller of Upstage-Downstage claimed, "There is a tendency for plays with a strong social justice message to become pedantic and sanctimonious, but, truly, we do not come to the theater to be lectured to.  So double kudos to Mr. Moss for presenting this story through a naturalistic recounting of the story."

We feel this is a moving story, and one that needs to be heard.






Other Ways You Can Help

If cannot contribute to our campaign, you can still help!

SPREAD THE WORD!  Part of the success of crowd-funding is simply reaching a large amount of people.  You can share this to people you know by using the Indiegogo share tools.

Contact us directly if you'd like to contribute outside of the online campaign.

Selected Reviews

“I’m loath to say very much at all about Death of the Persian Prince only because the less you know about what it has up its sleeve, the more powerful it is. However, playwright-director Dewey Moss has done his job so well, with this tight, taut play, that knowing “the big secret” may not diminish the impact but only heighten it differently. Death of the Persian Prince is an award-winning festival play... It’s very worthy of being offered by a subscription off-Broadway theatre company and being produced in the regionals ASAP. It’s a solid, provocative, well-rendered sleeper…that really keeps you awake.”

—David Spencer, Aisle Say

“Death of the Persian Prince is a play of substance and heart that deserves recognition and the opportunity to be more widely seen. There is a tendency for plays with a strong social justice message to become pedantic and sanctimonious, but, truly, we do not come to the theater to be lectured to. So double kudos to Mr. Moss for presenting this story through a naturalistic recounting.”

—Howard Miller, Upstage-Downstage

“ Death of the Persian Prince will surely change your thinking about the transgender community and the deep prejudice that surrounds the lives of the brave and heroic individuals who choose to celebrate who they have always been. Death of the Persian Prince remains one of the most riveting and life-altering plays in the current canon of LGBTQ theatre.”

—David Roberts, Theatre Reviews Ltd

“Dewey Moss’ powerful new drama is an important play...We must not forget the harrowing, tragic fate that the Iranian regime imposes on many members of Iran’s LGBT community. After seeing this play it seems impossible I’ll ever forget.”

—Nick Walther, UInterview.com

“Playwright Dewey Moss has crafted a well structured, taut, and seemingly conventional romance among clashing cultures that shockingly switches gears. Inventively based on news stories about situations in Iran, Mr. Moss skillfully weaves political issues into the dialogue among the characters and creates a plot that is gripping and painful. With fine simplicity Moss also directs this contained and emotionally charged play that features a trio of strong performances.”

—Darryl Reilly, TheaterScene.net

story:
Welcome to Speranza Theatre Company’s Indiegogo campaign for JANEY MILLER’S WORLD TOUR (JMWT), by John Cassel. Speranza is a professional theatre company located in Jersey City, NJ and this show rounds out our second season. JMWT was originally slated for fall 2014 until our talented playwright asked us to postpone the show in order to enter it in the Eugene O’Neill Playwrights Conference. It’s a good thing we held off on producing it - JMWT was named a semi-finalist in 2015…and THIS is the professional world premiere!

This hilarious modern day fairy tale proved to be a crowd pleaser - it’s fast paced, witty, and has the audience laughing out loud. When selecting our season, this was an obvious choice because the artists had as much fun working on the play as the audience had seeing it. We just couldn’t put this script down!

Thanks to a generous matching grant from The New Jersey State Council on the Arts, Administered by the Hudson County Office of Cultural and Heritage Affairs, Speranza is on the way to presenting the fully produced production of this romantic comedy this November, complete with a talented team of actors and a set that may seem like your favorite childhood set of wooden blocks has come to life. The grant we’ve received is a matching grant, and with the help of this Indiegogo campaign, Speranza will bring this play to life to entertain kids of all ages (appropriate for ages 12+.)

We still need $3,000 in order to complete our matching grant. This money will go straight to the production costs including: paying a professional team of artists, marketing materials, a fun set of life sized wooden blocks, and renting the beautiful new theatre where the show will take place.

We have several exciting perks selected just for YOU including autographed posters, VIP seating, personalized thank you videos from the cast and crew, and even secret discount codes for show tickets!

JANEY MILLER’S WORLD TOUR is important to Speranza because this play is another opportunity to connect with our community in many ways. Not only are these talented (and extremely funny) artists sharing this modern day fairy tale in an exciting production staged in the round this November 5th – 14th, Speranza is also connecting with our community by raising money for a local non-profit, WomenRising, on November 4th at our special “pay what you can” show. This production comes on the heels of successful 2015 performances of: THE VAGINA MONOLOGUES (raised money for WomenRising); SPRING FESTIVAL 2015; and several SEASONAL SHORTS readings. Speranza's 2014 season included: a professional production of A PIECE OF MY HEART, by Shirley Lauro (who was in attendance for opening night, which raised money for the local VFW); a FALL FESTIVAL original reading series; and a young adult show, MILLICENT THE MAGNIFICENT.

We have had some challenges to overcome but are continuously impressed by and feel welcomed by the Jersey City community. We are the new kids in town, so it is a challenge to continue spreading the word about the work we present. Many of the projects we present are either free or offer reduced pricing. It is our goal to expose as many people to great theatre as possible - all by professional artists, many who are members of the theatrical unions. Theatre is an art that is best when shared, and we are continuously trying new ways of reaching a broader audience through social media, newspapers, and interviews. Even with all these methods, we’ve found that the old-fashioned word of mouth is still the best way to reach an audience. We hope that you will join us for this laugh-out-loud modern day fairy tale – and be sure to spread the word. Even if you’re not able to contribute financially to this campaign, sharing this information is a fantastic way to offer support. Don’t forget to use the Indiegogo share tools to help us spread the word and make some noise. Thanks again and as always…see you at the show!

story:
Revenge is a dish best served HOT in this musical masterpiece of Halloween horror!

The Demon Barber of Fleet Street is coming to Salem Community Theatre!  Already a Tony Awarding-winning Broadway classic, SWEENEY TODD was recently made even more popular by the hit film starring Johnny Depp.  What's not to love about a demented barber driven mad by the destruction of his family, who cuts his victims' throats and sends them down a chute to be baked into meat pies by the enterprising proprietress of the shop below?  Based on the legend of 19th century London, SWEENEY TODD has it all:  thrills, chills, plenty of dark humor, brilliant and beautiful music--and yes, blood! 

 

  • In recent years, SCT's base has expanded beyond the Salem area, as people are drawn by its growing reputation for quality work.  In addition to our beloved core audience and performers, we are now proud to include residents of Akron, Youngstown, Canton and even Cleveland as members of our theatrical family!
  • This makes our responsibility to audiences and volunteers even greater:  we are determined to fulfill the scope and potential of this great classic--and it requires your help.

Help us do this show RIGHT:

Period costumes, razors that spurt blood, barber chairs that turn into expressways to hell,fog, lighting effects and more!  SWEENEY TODD is an ambitious production full of challenging technical issues that require a larger than normal budget.

  • We are looking to raise at least $500.  All funds will be applied directly to cover onstage production expenses.  
  • You will see your money well-spent onstage through improved production values of the show.
  • Check out the perks section to see what COOL STUFF you earn by donating--including a signed show poster, special Sweeney Todd t-shirt, and for the adventurous $250 donor--the chance to get your throat cut live onstage during a performance!

Your impact is major:

We know it's a big deal to donate money, and we don't take it lightly:

  • Director Michael Dempsey has a successful track record of fund-raising and pushing the envelope theatrically:  he raised over $1400 for a production of MACBETH at the Youngstown Playhouse that enabled them to use amazing effects like floating daggers and animatronic apparitions that thrilled audiences.  His background as a professional film and television writer and award-winning local director in NE Ohio ensures your money will be well-used.
  • We only ask when it will have special impact and bring added value to the audience, and SWEENEY is exactly that kind of adventure.
  • We are a nonprofit organization, so your donation is tax-deductible!

Great theatre leaves the comfort zone:

All theatres face the challenge of developing audiences in an age where attendance is declining, and SCT is no different.

  • SWEENEY TODD is a bold experiment in larger, more expensive productions that appeal to both its core subscribers and a wider contemporary audience.
  • Its success or failure will help determine how SCT programs shows in the future--help us push our boundaries and expand the kinds of shows we do!

If you can't contribute:

That's okay--there are plenty of other ways to help!

  • Make some bloody noise!  Get the word out--this show runs only two weekends and we KNOW we can sell out every house. 
  • Check out our Facebook Event at https://www.facebook.com/events/418800034989266.
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo awesome share tools!

story:
Four actors. Eleven characters. Pick Your Poison.  

A new theatre company, Madness Most Discreet presents The R+J Project: Romeo and Juliet Re-imagined. 

Rehearsed minimally, but studied intensely, MMD uses innovation and audience engagement to bring Shakespeare to the audience who actually knows what Trivia Crack is. Hint: It's not a drug. 

MMD revisits Shakespeare's stories and innovates through spontaneity and audience engagement for a younger generation. 

Madness Most Discreet Theatre was born from four actors experience with Original Practice Shakespearean Performance. MMD’s play on the Original Practice style is a performance where four actors each memorize the whole script of Romeo and Juliet,  and with a small amount of rehearsal leave the show in the audience’s hands, allowing the spectators to decide which actor will play what role. This “trial by fire” attitude in performance requires precision and specificity from its actors, but fosters incredible moments of discovery. "The R&J Project: Romeo and Juliet Reimagined” presents Shakespeare’s most famous star-crossed lovers like you’ve never seen them before. Our emphasis on the unknown and unrehearsed inspires fast-paced, spontaneous renderings of classic Shakespearean text. Inspired by renaissance traveling players, an MMD performance can take place at anytime, anywhere, requiring little more than the players’ bodies and voices. We bring to life Shakespeare's timeless stories through his eloquent words and the authenticity of spontaneous human interaction. This project promises moments of romance, lust, loss, and forgiveness, and that just begins to crack the surface of what is possible when we put YOU in control.

Since we are a fresh company, we need we all the help we can get. From rehearsal space, to materials such as scripts and folding chairs and having us travel up and down the east coast, we need some support. For real.

Visit madnessmostdiscreettheatre.com for more information and to get a sense for who we are.

And so you don't think we're just pocketing this money, here is a budget breakdown:
Materials  (Costumes, Properties, Set Pieces, Etc.):$400

Travel: $1000

Rehearsal Space: $900    
Venue Fees: $550
Advertising/PR/Marketing: $150

Education

Madness Most Discreet's  team of teaching artists also offers the opportunity for an interactive introduction to Shakespearean performance technique. In schools and recreation programs, possible classroom workshop topics may include, but are not limited to: text analysis, introduction to iambic pentameter, stage combat, and character creation. We want to bring Shakespeare to the next generation of creatives.

Rehearsed minimally, but studied intensely, MMD uses innovation and audience engagement to bring Shakespeare to the audience who actually knows what Trivia Crack is. Hint: It's not a drug. 
MMD revisits Shakespeare's stories and innovates through spontaneity and audience engagement for a younger generation. 
Madness Most Discreet Theatre was born from four actors experience with Original Practice Shakespearean Performance. MMD’s play on the Original Practice style is a performance where four actors each memorize the whole script of Romeo and Juliet,  and with a small amount of rehearsal leave the show in the audience’s hands, allowing the spectators to decide which actor will play what role. This “trial by fire” attitude in performance requires precision and specificity from its actors, but fosters incredible moments of discovery. "The R&J Project: Romeo and Juliet Reimagined” presents Shakespeare’s most famous star-crossed lovers like you’ve never seen them before. Our emphasis on the unknown and unrehearsed inspires fast-paced, spontaneous renderings of classic Shakespearean text. Inspired by renaissance traveling players, an MMD performance can take place at anytime, anywhere, requiring little more than the players’ bodies and voices. We bring to life Shakespeare's timeless stories through his eloquent words and the authenticity of spontaneous human interaction. This project promises moments of romance, lust, loss, and forgiveness, and that just begins to crack the surface of what is possible when we put YOU in control.
Since we are a fresh company, we need we all the help we can get. From rehearsal space, to materials such as scripts and folding chairs and having us travel up and down the east coast, we need some support. For real.
Visit madnessmostdiscreettheatre.com for more information and to get a sense for who we are.

And so you don't think we're just pocketing this money, here is a budget breakdown:


Materials  (Costumes, Properties, Set Pieces, Etc.):$400


Travel: $1000
Rehearsal Space: $900    

Venue Fees: $550
Advertising/PR/Marketing: $150



Education

Madness Most Discreet's  team of teaching artists also offers the opportunity for an interactive introduction to Shakespearean performance technique. In schools and recreation programs, possible classroom workshop topics may include, but are not limited to: text analysis, introduction to iambic pentameter, stage combat, and character creation. We want to bring Shakespeare to the next generation of creatives.

story:
YOU’RE INVITED

It’s New Year’s Eve. On the night of what seems to be a freak snowstorm in Singapore, six characters in a college cafe - each at turning points in their lives - are forced to confront their past and present in the face of a future that may forever remain imagined. 

Inspired by a collection of paintings by expressionist artist Sarah Shaw, SOMNOGRAM threads the themes of disconnect, isolation and death through a surrealistic exploration of the theories of dream interpretation and eternal recurrence. With a cast of intense and volatile characters, the play courts the audience to examine the conflict between our survival instincts and tendency for self-destruction, and to question the value of eternity, just as it lays bare the knowledge that we can never fully articulate what we really think and feel, and that we can never know - or be known - by someone else in perfect, absolute totality. SOMNOGRAM will be staged at the DBS Arts Centre - Home of SRT from 23-24 January 2015.

ABOUT THE COMPANY

Active since 2006, USP Productions is a youth-led theatre group formed by passionate individuals from the National University of Singapore's University Scholar's Programme. Focused on producing quality original work, USP Productions is the brainchild of student production teams, writers, designers and actors who have unified for a common cause: to create shows each year that reflect the hearts of youth in Singapore. Above all, we aim to stage plays that are meaningful and entertaining, reaching out to audiences both within campus and beyond. 

MAKE IT HAPPEN

Because this is a student-run production, any amount of donation will go a long way in bringing SOMNOGRAM to life! Your generous contribution will help us in these different aspects:

  • Venue Hire
  • Marketing
  • Insurance
  • Sets and Design
All of these cost money, and even if we don't meet our goals, your contributions will help us recover these costs.

What could be better than giving young people a voice?

We have big dreams. SOMNOGRAM will be the ninth production led by student production teams of writers, designers and actors to exhibit the true essence of the youth society in Singapore. 


BUILD, SUPPORT, INSPIRE

Your impact is personal. If you love theatre, if you care about youths and if you enjoy being stimulated intellectually and artistically, you'll be helping to build a medium for creativity and expression.

Your impact is philosophical. SOMNOGRAM explores the philosophical themes of eternal recurrence and its impact on philosophy, religion and even pop culture. We want to provide a mouthpiece for people - especially young people - to connect, talk and explore this issue further. We hope that SOMNOGRAM is able to add something meaningful to this conversation. 

Your impact is societal. The arts in Singapore is expensive. We're working with the university faculty and administration to make our play accessible to financially disadvantaged students, and to donate our proceeds to a needy students' fund. Your contribution will go a long way to helping those who need it more than us.

ABOUT THE PLAYWRIGHT

Denise recently graduated from NUS where she majored in English Literature. Deeply passionate about the arts, she is grateful for opportunities to stage Somnogram and co-direct Patchwork(2014) under USProductions. Her creative work has been published in literary outlets such as Afterglobe Magazine, and her short screenplay was a finalist at Toronto’s WILDSound Film Festival (2013). She is also a current recipient of the NAC’s Mentor Access Project.

SPREAD THE WORD

Help us tell everybody about SOMNOGRAM! It doesn't matter if you live in Singapore, the USA, or Antarctica! YOU have the power to empower people across the world with a few simple clicks.

Check out our facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/productions.usc?fref=ts and share it with your friends! Also, share this very page by clicking on one of the social media links below. Every contribution, monetary or otherwise, counts!

story:
A New Company's Dreams

Infused Quirk has had quite an inaugural year: a full scale production of CARRIE THE MUSICAL, a Fall Dramatic Reading of DOGFIGHT THE MUSICAL, and its benefit cabarets IF YOU'VE GOT, HAUNT IT and NEVER WILL I EVER. Aside from our musicians, our company functions off of the volunteer efforts of the community.

As a new company, our goal has been to use musical theatre to reach out to the community in unique ways. Our next adventure is to take our productions to the next level by exploring a variety of art forms: more specifically, photography and performance art.

From January 2015 up to May 2015, a small group of local performers will come together to challenge one another as singers, as actors, as storytellers, and as visionaries in a safe space where we can interpret text, music, stories, and humanity. Through this unique rehearsal process, we will be collaborating to create stories that not only speak to our audience, but allows them to enter this safe space.

Time stopped by a photograph:
Time stopped, a moment split in half.
Stop time, captured light.
It's the final claim for what's in the frame,
It's not right, it's not wrong.
In its depth, its height,
Its color, its plight,
Its wonder, its song
It's what's in sight.

Make These Dreams Come True

Through community service at a local theater in West Orange, NJ and through several fundraising events since September 2014, IQ has secured its performance space and paid for about half of the amount to license the show. However, we are still in financial need to create a professional product. Your donations will go to the following areas:

  • Licensing and rental materials from Samuel French
  • Stipends for professional musicians
  • Minor technical expendables (light gels, cabling)

With every donation, we've got some great items up for grabs. This not only includes merchandise, but also puts you in the seats of the production.

Be Part of the Bridge

Infused Quirk offers unique opportunities that actively engage and positively inspire our community whether you are onstage, backstage, or part of our audience, through the vehicle of a fully realized and developed theatrical production. We are not only bringing artists together, but we are bridging the gap between our community and our art.


SPREAD THE WORD!!

Can't donate right now? Share our inspiration with your friends and family. On Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and good, ol' fashioned word of mouth.

story:
Short Summary

The Sleigh Belle Dancers are a self-managed, volunteer holiday dance ensemble based in Minneapolis. We dance at a variety of locations throughout the Twin Cities, including nursing homes and hospitals.

Our team includes teenagers and retirees, mothers and teachers, daughters and breast-cancer survivors. We come from many backgrounds, but we have one common goal: to give back to our community and spread the holiday spirit to people who need it most.

This campaign will help us maintain our basic expenses so that we can continue to provide high quality performances in our community. 

What We Need & What You Get

All of our dancers are volunteers -- we perform because we love to dance and we love to spread holiday cheer.

As a self-managed group, we encounter a lot of expenses. Our goal is to raise $5000 to cover:

  • choreography and facilities fees
  • costumes and supplies
  • equipment costs
  • incidental expenses

We couldn’t dance without these!

And because we love the spirit of giving, we have some great perks for YOU when you contribute to our campaign!

Check out the following contribution levels:

Cupid -- $15

To show our love and appreciation, we'll send you a heart-filled thank you note -- featuring a picture of our danceline and signed by the Sleigh Belle Dancers!

Blitzen -- $35

Show YOUR holiday spirit! You'll get a red short-sleeve t-shirt featuring the Sleigh Belle Dancers signature sleigh (with a Santa hat, of course) to let people know you are a Sleigh Belle supporter. (plus $15-level perk)

Dasher -- $100

Dashing through the mall to shop? Stop and watch the Sleigh Belle Dancers, and keep your treasures protected in your gorgeous Sleigh Belle Dancers shopping tote. (plus $15- and $35-level perks)

Dancer -- $300

The Sleigh Belle Dancers will perform at your event (in the Minneapolis/St. Paul metro area) in November or December 2015 or January 2016 (date to be agreed upon). Performance includes 2 jazz/kick holiday dances (dances can be repeated). ONLY 3 AVAILABLE!


The Impact of the Sleigh Belle Dancers

It is so powerful for us to see the impact of our performances.

Several years ago we performed at the Veterans Hospital in Minneapolis. After our show, a woman came up to us with tears in her eyes. She told us that her husband, facing a long hospital stay over the holidays, had been really down, and just didn’t think that it would really be Christmas that year. Our performance brought a smile to his face, and she told us that we had made her month. ❤

THAT’S why we dance.

Dance truly is an expression of the human spirit. We would be honored if you would contribute to our campaign so we can continue to spread joy and cheer and compassion to those who need it most during the upcoming holiday season.


Other Ways You Can Help

We know some people are unable to contribute financially, but you can still support the Sleigh Belle Dancers!

  • Follow us on Facebook and help promote our campaign!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools up by our video on this page!

Thank you so much for contributing, sharing, and helping us make the holiday season a bit brighter. We are humbled by and deeply grateful for your generosity.

story:
The Delphi Opera House Countdown to Reopening!

2009...

Now...

After years in the planning and a $4.3 million restoration, the Delphi Opera House is set to reopen its doors in October 2015! Located on the third floor of the historic Assion-Ruffing City Hall, the Delphi Opera House is a 200+ seat venue in charming downtown Delphi, Indiana. During the 1880s through the mid-1910s, the Delphi Opera House was the entertainment center for a bustling community. The stage is set for it to be that once again, but we your need to help to make that happen.

The Delphi Preservation Society has been leading the charge on the restoration of this historic theater since 1996 when it purchased two-thirds of the building acquiring the remaining third in 2011. Early attention focused on restoring the facade of the building, replacing the roof, and beginning the design process for renovating the structure. As plans evolved, the vision became more and more clear: create a facility that restores the look and feel of the historic theater but with all of the amenities needed for a fully-accessible community center and performance venue. Pretty ambitious for an all-volunteer organization in a community of only 3,000!


What We Have Accomplished and What We Need

We have most of the big stuff covered--the elevator, fire stairs, modern restrooms, dressing rooms, banquet hall--even sound and video equipment.  We have merited some amazing assistance along the way through Indiana Stellar Community grants, a challenge award from the Jeffris Family Foundation, a generous grant from NCHS administered through the Tippecanoe Arts Federation, and many corporate and individual contributors!

However, after our $4.3 million restoration, there are still some bills to pay and debt to service. And we still need to finish outfitting the facility to make sure it runs smoothly and lives up to expectations!

So, we find ourselves with the doors opening in just weeks and lots of needs still requiring funding. Here is a short list of what is remaining and a range of dollars that we could spend on each:

  • Basic theatrical lighting ... $15 - $40K
  • Phone and WiFi equipment ... $8 - $21K
  • Appliances for our caterer's kitchen ... $9 - 15K
  • Floor mats, wastebaskets, mops, buckets, cleaning supplies ... $2 - $3K
  • All of the other million things that you don't think of before "opening day"... $1K

Taking the low end of the dollar amounts, the Delphi Opera House could open effectively and acquire the addition items needed as cash begins to flow "in and out"  rather than just "out."

The Impact

So, why should you give to this campaign? Why is it important?

The truth of the matter is that we can limp into our opening season without these items. However, we would take away of the "grandeur" from our Grand Opening! Particularly the theatrical lighting!

Risks & Challenges

The Delphi Opera House will open its doors for tours and benefit events in September.  The Grand Opening events are scheduled for October!  The Opera House is stunning and will cause many oohs and ahs!  The experience of attending an event whether a concert, theater performance, wedding, or any other event will be an experience not soon forgotten.  We have most of the big stuff covered--the elevator, fire stairs, modern restrooms, sound and video equipment. Now we need to finish outfitting the interior to make sure the facility runs smoothly! 

We need to keep our guests’ experience a pleasant one.  Therefore we need help with the small things like wastebaskets, recycling containers, drink coolers, appliances to make coffee, paper products in the restrooms, and more! And, we need a few not-so-small-things, like fixtures to light the stage!


    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't spare some dollars, how about giving some hours?

    • Volunteer! We need greeters, ticket takers, ushers, sound and lighting techs, marketing and social meeting gurus, and more!
    • And, you can help by simply sharing our campaign with your friends on Facebook, Twitter, or elsewhere!

story:
Wir sind der kurtheater bitterfeld e.V. dessau-roßlau, ein freier Theaterverein aus Dessau, der sich mit aktuellen kulturellen, sozialen und politischenThemen auseinandersetzt.

Unsere Geschichte

Plastik ist der Stoff unserer Zeit: er ist leicht, billig und für alles verwendbar. Leider nimmt sich die Industrie diesen Grundsatz zu sehr zu Herzen und flutet den Planeten mit Plastikerzeugnissen. Jedes Jahr gelangen bis zu 10 Mio. Tonnen dieses Mülls in die Ozeane. An unseren Stränden landen die Plastikflaschen und auf den Meeren sammeln sich kontinentgroße Müllstrudel.

Plastikmüll am Ufer des Roten Meeres - Foto Vberger

Der Plastikmüll wird im Laufe der Zeit immer weiter zerkleinert und gelangt schließlich in Form von Mikroplastik zurück in die Nahrungskette. Die Auswirkungen auf die Meereslebewesen und schließlich den Menschen sind unvorhersehbar.

Die Projektleiterin Regula Steiner-Tomic beobachtet diesen Trend seit einigen Jahren mit wachsender Sorge. Als sie am Strand einen Schwarm Fische sieht, der zwischen den Plastikteilen im Wasser hin- und her schwimmt, kommt ihr ein Gedanke. Was wäre, wenn sich die Fische in einem Kollektiv zusammenschlossen? Was, wenn sie sich versammelten und aufbegehrten gegen die Zerstörung ihres Lebensraums?

So wurde dieses Projekt ins Leben gerufen.

Das Kollektiv der Fische - Foto Philipp Keitel


Unsere Mittel sind die des Theaters. Wir wollen die Müllproblematik auf spielerische, komödiantische und clowneske Art und Weise reflektieren und die Menschen dafür sensibilisieren.

Die Premiere des Stücks ist auf dem Bauhausfest in Dessau, am 05.09.2015!
Für Erwachsene und Kinder ab 8 Jahren.

Der Name ist Programm:
Jetzt sind wir "das Kollektiv der Fische". Eure Unterstützung ermutigt uns, den Weg weiter zu gehen und weiter zu arbeiten, um schließlich ein großes Parlament einzuberufen und ein großes Stück auf die internationale Bühne zu bringen.


Erste Entwürfe für das Bühnenbild werden besprochen - Foto Dragan Dragin


Was du uns gibst & was du bekommst

Alle Beteiligten arbeiten aus Begeisterung für die Sache und das Projekt. Im Moment geschieht das komplett ehrenamtlich und ohne Gage.

Mit Eurer Unterstützung ermöglicht Ihr uns, mit der Theaterarbeit weiterzumachen und so vielen Menschen wie möglich die Problematik der Plastikverschmutzung nahezubringen. In den 15000 € sind enthalten:

  • Aufwandsentschädigungen für sechs Schauspieler und das Team (Projektleitung, Regie, Szenenbild, Kostümbild)
  • Kosten für Szenenbild und Kostüme
  • Erstellung einer Webseite

Der Fisch als Leitmotiv - Foto Dragan Dragin

Ihr bekommt:
  • Eine Theaterperformance im "Aquarium" (Hochschulgebäude 08) der Hochschule Anhalt
  • sowie eine Outdoorperformance auf dem Bauhausfest 2015
  • Weitere Vorstellungen in Sachsen-Anhalt und Umgebung

Unsere Perks erlauben es Euch, Theater hautnah zu erleben und das Projektteam kennenzulernen.

Wenn wir unser Funding-Ziel nicht erreichen, könnte es sein, dass wir mit einer kleineren Besetzung auftreten, was sehr schade wäre.


Die Folgen

Wir glauben, dass die Vermüllung unserer Gewässer eines der dringensten Probleme der Gegenwart ist. Wir möchten erreichen, dass besonders die junge Generation rücksichtsvoll mit der Natur umgeht und mit einem ausgeprägten Umweltbewusstsein aufwächst. Deswegen konzipieren wir unser Stück für alle Altersgruppen.

Im Mai 2015 haben wir in Kotor, Montenegro, einen Workshop mit Kindern abgehalten. Die Kinder haben mit uns am Strand Müll gesammelt und über ihre Erfahrungen Geschichten erzählt. Für August ist ein weiterer Workshop geplant.

Unsere Kostümbildnerin, Sabin Groeflin, betreut zur Zeit in einer Berliner Grundschule ein Schultheaterprojekt, das sich mit der Thematik auseinandersetzt.

Unsere Regisseurin für die Außenperformance, Biljana Golubovic, hat 2014 in Mexico erfolgreich das Theaterprojekt "Todos somos laguna" (Wir sind die Lagune) geleitet, das sich mit der Umweltzerstörung durch einen Staudamm beschäftigte.


Andere Wege, wie man helfen kann

Wenn ihr uns nicht finanziell unterstützen könnt oder wollt, gibt es trotzdem viele Wege uns zu helfen:

  • Erzählt Euren Freunden von unserem Projekt
  • Teilt unsere Facebook-Seite oder unser Video
  • Achtet mehr auf die Umwelt!
story_txt:
Wir sind der kurtheater bitterfeld e.V. dessau-roßlau, ein freier Theaterverein aus 
Dessau, der sich mit aktuellen kulturellen, sozialen und politischenThemen 
auseinandersetzt. 
Unsere Geschichte
Plastik ist der Stoff unserer Zeit: er ist leicht, billig und für alles verwendbar. Leider nimmt sich die Industrie diesen Grundsatz zu sehr zu Herzen und flutet den Planeten mit Plastikerzeugnissen. Jedes Jahr gelangen bis zu 10 Mio. Tonnen dieses Mülls in die Ozeane. An unseren Stränden landen die Plastikflaschen und auf den Meeren sammeln sich kontinentgroße Müllstrudel. 
Plastikmüll am Ufer des Roten Meeres - Foto Vberger Der Plastikmüll wird im Laufe der Zeit immer weiter zerkleinert und gelangt schließlich in Form von Mikroplastik zurück in die Nahrungskette. Die Auswirkungen auf die Meereslebewesen und schließlich den Menschen sind unvorhersehbar.Die Projektleiterin Regula Steiner-Tomic beobachtet diesen Trend seit einigen Jahren mit wachsender Sorge. Als sie am Strand einen Schwarm Fische sieht, der zwischen den Plastikteilen im Wasser hin- und her schwimmt, kommt ihr ein Gedanke. Was wäre, wenn sich die Fische in einem Kollektiv zusammenschlossen? Was, wenn sie sich versammelten und aufbegehrten gegen die Zerstörung ihres Lebensraums? So wurde dieses Projekt ins Leben gerufen. Das Kollektiv der Fische - Foto Philipp Keitel
Unsere Mittel sind die des Theaters. Wir wollen die Müllproblematik auf spielerische, komödiantische und clowneske Art und Weise reflektieren und die Menschen dafür sensibilisieren.Die Premiere des Stücks ist auf dem Bauhausfest in Dessau, am 05.09.2015!Für Erwachsene und Kinder ab 8 Jahren.Der Name ist Programm:Jetzt sind wir "das Kollektiv der Fische". Eure Unterstützung ermutigt uns, den Weg weiter zu gehen und weiter zu arbeiten, um schließlich ein großes Parlament einzuberufen und ein großes Stück auf die internationale Bühne zu bringen.


Erste Entwürfe für das Bühnenbild werden besprochen - Foto Dragan Dragin
  
Was du uns gibst & was du bekommst Alle Beteiligten arbeiten aus Begeisterung für die Sache und das Projekt. Im Moment geschieht das komplett ehrenamtlich und ohne Gage.
Mit Eurer Unterstützung ermöglicht Ihr uns, mit der Theaterarbeit weiterzumachen und so vielen Menschen wie möglich die Problematik der Plastikverschmutzung nahezubringen. In den 15000 € sind enthalten:

Aufwandsentschädigungen für sechs Schauspieler und das Team (Projektleitung, Regie, Szenenbild, Kostümbild)
Kosten für Szenenbild und Kostüme
Erstellung einer Webseite



Der Fisch als Leitmotiv - Foto Dragan DraginIhr bekommt:
Eine Theaterperformance im "Aquarium" (Hochschulgebäude 08) der Hochschule Anhalt
sowie eine Outdoorperformance auf dem Bauhausfest 2015

Weitere Vorstellungen in Sachsen-Anhalt und Umgebung

Unsere Perks erlauben es Euch, Theater hautnah zu erleben und das Projektteam kennenzulernen.
Wenn wir unser Funding-Ziel nicht erreichen, könnte es sein, dass wir mit einer kleineren Besetzung auftreten, was sehr schade wäre.

    Die Folgen Wir glauben, dass die Vermüllung unserer Gewässer eines der dringensten Probleme der Gegenwart ist. Wir möchten erreichen, dass besonders die junge Generation rücksichtsvoll mit der Natur umgeht und mit einem ausgeprägten Umweltbewusstsein aufwächst. Deswegen konzipieren wir unser Stück für alle Altersgruppen.
Im Mai 2015 haben wir in Kotor, Montenegro, einen Workshop mit Kindern abgehalten. Die Kinder haben mit uns am Strand Müll gesammelt und über ihre Erfahrungen Geschichten erzählt. Für August ist ein weiterer Workshop geplant.
Unsere Kostümbildnerin, Sabin Groeflin, betreut zur Zeit in einer Berliner Grundschule ein Schultheaterprojekt, das sich mit der Thematik auseinandersetzt.
Unsere Regisseurin für die Außenperformance, Biljana Golubovic, hat 2014 in Mexico erfolgreich das Theaterprojekt "Todos somos laguna" (Wir sind die Lagune) geleitet, das sich mit der Umweltzerstörung durch einen Staudamm beschäftigte.

story:
Introduction
Hello, I'm Sandra Kammann. I need your support to underwrite my upcoming production, Duir-wyyd: The Dreamer's Doorway, which will premiere in October as part of the Women's Voices Theater Festival. The Festival is intended to give voice to the works of women artists, who are traditionally underfunded and underrepresented in the theatre community. Contributions in any amount will help give voice to my work. I look forward to seeing you at the show!!

Women’s Voices Theatre Festival   www.womensvoicestheaterfestival.org/plays/Duir-wyyd 

The Play

Driven by activist passion and anthropological training, playwright Sandra Kammann’s new work tackles religious persecution, eco-spirituality, the mother-daughter bond and the nature of eternity, for starters. The hallmark alchemy of her mythic approach is deliciously nourishing, and the play’s visionary perspective proves both disarming and exhilarating in its bold authenticity. With a stirring musical score, luscious vocals, ancient poetic lore and arresting physical-theatre, Duir-wyyd: The Dreamer’s Doorway weaves tangible magic, offering a compelling message for our time.

While navigating life’s challenges, Melissa feels the widening gap between her dreams for the future and her daily existence. When she and her teenaged daughter Claire find themselves displaced, a sense of powerless mediocrity threatens to overtake her once buoyant nature.  When the dreams begin, she is unaware of their meaning, and the gifts they offer.  Startled awake, she hears retreating voices singing a familiar blessing in a language she no longer comprehends. Through the portal of her dreams, the story of Duir-wyyd: The Dreamer’s Doorway unfolds.

Set in contemporary Washington D.C. and in ancient Ireland, the heart of the play follows a band of Druids, members of an illuminated spiritual elite revered as practitioners of ancient Celtic wisdom. “Duir-wyyd” or “Druid” translates as one who can traverse the veil between the worlds to experience and transmit sacred knowledge. Allied with the spirits of Nature, Druids were the shamanic leaders of their time, tending to their people as healers, bards and visionaries. As Rome’s reach expands and the church’s influence grows, a monumental struggle over the fate of the people of the Isle of Eire ensues. Drawn into this world in her dreams, Melissa’s revelations rock her world!

TICKETS ON SALE NOW!!

Silver Spring Black Box Theatre

RESERVE TICKETS: 

https://wethetemple.tixato.com/buy

Saturday, October 24 @ 7:30 PM                                                                       Sunday, October 25 @ 3:00 PM                                                                               8641 Colesville Road, Silver Spring, MD


Spooky Action Theater  

RESERVE TICKETS: 

https://spookyaction.secure.force.com/ticket

Saturday, October 31 @ 7:30 PM                                                                       Sunday, November 1 @ 3:00 PM                                                                              1810 16th Street N.W., Washington , D.C. 


About the Playwright / Director 

Sandra Kammann: playwright, director, choreographer, cultural anthropologist, activist  and lifelong practitioner of Transformational Theatre and mystical ritual traditions. Founding Artistic Director: Sisters of One Eye Dance/Theatre Troupe. Playwright & Director: Crack Between the Worlds: the goddess returns (adaptation, Aeschylus’ The Eumenides), produced by Studio Theatre’s Secondstage: Helen Hayes nomination for Best Musical (Deborah Wicks-La Puma, composer & Music Director). Faculty: The John F. Kennedy Center Community Partnerships Initiative; Studio Theatre Acting Conservatory (1992-2013). M.A. Cultural Anthropology: Transformational Theatre (Honors), The George Washington University

THE CAST

Mary Abbott, Craig Allen, A.J. Calbert, Miss Jessica Denson, Madelyn Farris, Madison Middleton, Vanessa Nolan, Lilian Oben, Carol Spring

DESIGNERS & CONSULTANTS

Romula Hawthorn, Lynn Sharp Spears, Cheryl Foster, Denise Diggs, Shannon Dunne, Matt Jones, Rebecca Carle
