story:
Who We Are

We are the Wilsor Theatrical Group; a collective of like-minded artists who have come together to produce theatre that is Underdone and Over Easy. 
It is our goal to produce theatrical events that are under represented in the community and give audiences an opportunity to experience these rare theatrical treasures.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $7,500 to help launch our first season. This money will go toward renting our performance venue, paying musicians, insurance costs, and Administrative fees such as postage, website management, and marketing materials. In return we will provide you with an array of different packages that include signed memorabilia, tickets, and more. All donations are tax-deductible thanks to our partnership with Fractured Atlas. 

The Impact

In addition to providing access to the entire community to shows that are rarely seen; we are providing art to a community that is underserved due to its proximity to New York City. The Surrounding New Jersey area is an overlooked resource for producing great theatre and we will be providing that to the Newark and Jersey City communities by offering affordable performances close to home.

Through our Over Easy Production, we will also be providing other artists an opportunity to be seen by a wider range of patron by giving them a stage on which to perform.

Risks & Challenges

The risks & challenges for all new theatrical ventures are always similar. The first is being taken seriously and getting people to come. The second is funding your initial production. We believe that with the experience and expertise that Dustin can provide from his past successful projects, we will be able to maneuver these obstacles easily & create a venue known for "must see theatre".

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to your money; we are looking for artists interested in being part of our collective, as well as suggestions of the shows that you believe are Underdone. If you are interested in participating in either of these capacities please visit www.wilsortheatricals.com and submit your suggestions there.

story:
My name is Deraya Rose and I am 11 years old. **update, I just turned 12**  I currently have my own cleaning business to help raise money for acting, modeling and dancing. My mom is teaching me to earn what I can to get me where I want to go and then my mom & dad try to pay for the rest. In school (I have the best school in the world) I maintain straight A's. I am called a nerd, geek, good two shoes A LOT but I do not let that bring me down. I still get to do what I love to do.

I started acting 2 years ago and it started with a small part in a play. I fell in love with it and it is now my passion and goal. In my short amount of time I have been in a few movies and worked with people like George Lopez (I was a background extra only but I still loved being on set with him; we took pictures together). The last 2 years I have also gone to acting camp in CA, called Young Actors Theater Camp, or CAMPYATC.COM, where I have taken classes from Naomi Grossman (American Horror Stories-she is Pepper), Candi Milo (Voice for Dexter Cartoon), and many more. The camp directors Shawn Ryan and John Ainsworth are the BEST!!! They have been in many sitcoms themselves. I also take classes with Casting Director Helen McCready, CSA. Good Faith Casting helped me get into Car Dogs! Faith and Bella are awesome peeps.

I started tap dancing in January 2014. I also fell in love with dance! I could express myself in another way. I joined Cindy Jellison with the All Star Dance Center in Show Low, AZ as an official student in Nov. 2014 and in Feb. 2015 I went to my first dance competition with 'Step up 2 Dance". I entered as a novice and I won a high gold. Miss Carol invited me to Nationals in July in NH!!! But we cannot afford to go sadly. It is such an honor getting chosen to do something like this when I have little dance experience. April 2015 I went to my 2nd dance competition in El Paso, TX with KAR. I won a top 1st place, 7th place in overall score, I placed 6th for a title in Miss Junior dance and now I get to go to Nationals again but this time in Vegas AND I was also 3 out of 42 dancing acts that was chosen to go to NYC in July (the week before Vegas) and I get to take many Master Classes and train with the ROCKETTES!!!! From Broadway!!!

I have 2 other dance competitions coming up, both in AZ (the state I live in) plus I have a master class in CA at the end of April I need to attend if I am going to take my dancing, acting career to the next level. 

I am also a certified youth referee with AYSO. I play soccer, basketball and I used to play softball.

That is where you come in. My dad is the only one who works. He is the manager at our local Ford Dealership in Show Low, AZ. We live 3 hours away form Phoenix up on the White Mountains. Our community is SMALL. My mom and dad do the best they can to pay for my things but sometimes I need help. Like now! After bills and my extras, we are still living paycheck to paycheck. Most people think we are rich but my mom has to be careful which roles she submits me for so that anything I am paid, covers our trip. But this builds my resume up and it gets me noticed a little more each time.

I am needing to raise $5000 or more to be able to go to NY! This covers my mom and myself plus airfare. If my brother and sister go, a lot more. NY is a long way away from AZ. Most things I get to do is in the South West because we have a hard enough time paying for those.

Thank you for your donation and helping a child live her dreams!!

my facebook page:

https://www.facebook.com/DerayaRose.DancingActr...

**Disclaimer: My mother helped me write this**
story_txt: My name is Deraya Rose and I am 11 years old. **update, I just turned 12**  I currently have my own cleaning business to help raise money for acting, modeling and dancing. My mom is teaching me to earn what I can to get me where I want to go and then my mom & dad try to pay for the rest. In school (I have the best school in the world) I maintain straight A's. I am called a nerd, geek, good two shoes A LOT but I do not let that bring me down. I still get to do what I love to do. I started acting 2 years ago and it started with a small part in a play. I fell in love with it and it is now my passion and goal. In my short amount of time I have been in a few movies and worked with people like George Lopez (I was a background extra only but I still loved being on set with him; we took pictures together). story:
My Story

Of all the luxuries that money can afford, Time is what I most need right now.

Being the kind of writer that I am, I'm always too close to my work; writing often in between between the lines. When my work asks me to step back and give it a fresh look, I do. But after working on a piece for so long to get it just right, there comes a point when stepping back isn't enough. I have now to sit back and watch what I've written.

My Play's Journey

I began writing this play in 2012 which might explain why I currently have three versions.

First is the One Act version. I used that as my thesis project which my grad school, The Actors Studio of Drama School at Pace University in New York, professionally produced in our Rep season under the title Less Than the Number Three. The result? People liked it. It was well received.

The second version is what I'd like to call the behemoth version; a Three Act play with an approximate run time of 120 minutes. Same story, same two characters but with an additional character and a much bigger (perhaps too big) theme. I titled it Walking Lovers.

To say people didn't like it would be an understatement. And I don't blame them. Although I'm still hopeful I can make sense out of it someday, there's just too much happening all at once and not enough shifts to highlight my ungodly reason. So clearly, that's going in the drawers until further notice.

The third, best (I'm sure) and final version (I hope) is...


Synopsis

It is the 12th of February, 2012. Girma and Samrawit are a couple living in an apartment somewhere in Washington Heights, New York.  She's a student at Columbia and he's a suit salesman in midtown. It is the (mid-season) premiere of their favorite show of all time, The Walking Dead. As per their ritual, they go out to get their special pizza. By the time they return, they're fighting in their usual duel of wits. Only this night, it leads to their break-up.

And the next morning brings them (to) Truth.

BUDGET BREAKDOWN

       Venue : Audition + Rehearsal + Performance       =  $3,000
          Staff : Designers + Builders + Stage Manager   =  $3,000
             Set : Construction + Rental + Transportation =  $2,500
Marketing : Promotional + Production materials        = $ 1,000
Extra Fund : Actors compensation + Concessions     = $    500
                                                                                     TOTAL  = $10,000

PERFORMANCE DATES

Three Week Run:

Opening JULY 16TH - Closing AUGUST 1ST

Thursday to Sunday - 8pm


Risks & Challenges

  • MAY - 31 days to raise the money.
  • JUNE - 30 days to secure location, cast the show and hire my crew.
  • JULY - rehearse and have a great show.


BEST WAY YOU CAN HELP

Share, love!


DISCLAIMER

So, some of my friends have expressed their concern over my video that it doesn't accurately portray the level of enthusiasm I feel about my own work. Even though those who know me understand where I'm coming from, for those who don't there's a good chance I come off as disinterested and fatigued. But that isn't true. Make no mistake, I am fatigued beyond measure and unbelievably disinterested in attempting to put up an 'image' or a 'brand' for myself - The Excited Playwright about His exciting New work! Ironically, I am very excited and my play is very dope but that's not the point. 

You will also find that my written pitch doesn't particularly inspire confidence nor positively capture the extent of my talent. I apologize if that deters you from donating but I will not apologize for choosing to be brave and exposing my struggle.

I am far from the best version of myself but I will not get there if I'm parading like I already have. What I do have is a set of skills (help me Liam Neeson!), a set of skills that are unique to me and to my vision which you will have the opportunity to see if you trust me enough and have faith when I tell you "Believe in me. Because I do".

story:
Short Summary

 Characters Stage Company is a youth theatre group  set up by Producer Moira Townsend Williams in November 2012 to provide new opportunities for young people to produce creative, innovative new writing. Every year we produce a new play for performance, and this year our company is made up of 21 young people aged 10-20 who have been working  since October 2014 with Bristol In Residence writer, Tom Wainwright, and director Sara Griffiths on creating a new play exploring  the so called 'gap' between the generations.Through this devising process a  new play 'Mind The Gap' has evolved- a humorous yet insightful play that addresses serious themes common to everyone of all ages.
The play is on at the Arc Theatre, Trowbridge on Saturday July 4th at 7pm and Sunday July 5th 3.30pm and 7pm. Tickets £10/£8 available from Arc Box Office 01225 756376 or arctheatre.org( Age Guide 10+).Free tickets are also included in our 'Perks' page so please  take a look!)

The action  takes place in a care home, where a small group of teenagers on the run from the police  seek refuge. Unwittingly stuck together for a couple of hours,the elderly residents and the teenagers are forced to get to know each other. The characters relate stories from their past, or about their own lives and gradually come to realise that the generation ‘gap’ is not the gulf they originally thought.The play starts off with heightened comedy, but this is stripped away  to reveal  the real issues and dilemmas that each of them face, or have faced  in their lives. Finally a  surprising truth is revealed in the plays' dramatic and poignant conclusion.This play will appeal to everyone aged from from 10 to 100 years old.

What We Need & What You Get

Although we have received some funding from Arts Council England, as well as Bradford on Avon Town Council and The Colonel Llewellen Palmer Educational Charity, we need just £500 more  towards  costume and set, which will bring the play to life and really give the participants a sense of being in a professional production. What you get  by supporting u with your donations, s are some amazing 'Perks' such as free tickets, an overnight stay at The Castle Inn  - Bradford on Avon,  a meal out at the newly opened Wagamama   and signed programmes by tomorrow's stars! Plus of course you have the benefit of knowing that you are  helping so many local young people  to perform!

The Impact

Your contribution will make a real difference to our cast of 21 young people, as we give them a real experience of putting on a professional production, complete with set and costumes. Our professional Set Designer Carmen di Lemos and our professional Lighting/Sound designer Charlie Lepage-Norris have been working  on a fabulous set/costume/lighting design and now we just need a bit more money to bring it to life!

Characters Stage Company has been going since November 2012 and has already produced two successful plays seen by hundreds of local people. FACELESS An Anti-Social Media Drama explored the effects social media is having on society, and DREAMCATCHER  a play  about following your dreams in a world that wants you to forget , were both based on  the youth group's ideas  with the young people devising around themes they wanted to explore. Our ethic is to  give young people an outlet to  express themselves, and  help them validate their ideas and opinions  by using the medium of theatre. Our plays often challenge pre-conceptions about  youth culture and throw up interesting ideas for debate.

Risks & Challenges

It has always been risky producing new theatre. Attracting the participants and an audience who wants to see their work is always a challenge. By the nature of the work, when we begin our journey in October, we often have no idea about how it is going to turn out by the performance in early July. This of course is the same for all theatre that is produced, but most productions start off with a script and a director's vision for that piece. We start off with just  a group of young people, a writer, a director and a theme. Where it will go is anyone's guess but we always impress upon the group that they must trust the process and magical things will happen! As Goethe said "Whatever you can do, or dream you can do, begin it now". That is what we must do at the beginning  of each Characters Stage Company  project. We know that if we trust , great things will happen! Getting in the final money that we need is one of the challenges that I, as producer faces each year  as we approach the end phase of our project. But I trust that the right people will  come  forward and help us and each year I am amazed not only by the generosity of individuals, but also by the faith of the community's local businesses in rallying round to provide the wonderful "Perks' that we offer on each project.See our Perks page and get involved!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute by buying one of the 'Perks' you can help spread the word on your Facebook account and share the link to this site with all your friends be they local to the  Trowbridge area or not. You can use the Indegogo share Tools to do this- we are so grateful for anything anyone can do to help us. We are also  doing a 'Talent show Fundraiser at the Arc Theatre on Monday June 1st at 7pm-just a casual fun event where the young people can show off their talents in a relaxed and supportive environment. Tickets on the door are £5 or you may have a raffle prize you are  r able to donate-contact me  moira@charactersstageschool.com

With your support, great things can happen!

story:
There are many NYC schoolchildren who have never seen live theater.
You can change that.

Join The Fantasticks, the world's longest running musical, in introducing NYC schoolchildren to the wonder of live theater. Our goal is to send as many children to their first theater performance at no cost to them.

What We Need & What You Get

A ticket to The Fantasticks costs $76, we're trying to send at least 1,000 at $25/ticket.

In addition to sending a child to The Fantasticks your donation can get you:
  • Exclusive merch from The Fantasticks
  • Complimentary tickets to the show
  • Thank you notes/videos from the students & teachers that your contributions help send to The Fantasticks.

The Impact

The Fantasticks Kids in the Theater program is an arts education initiative which sends NYC public school children to see The Fantasticks, the world's longest-running musical, at no cost to them. The program is targeted to public schools with children who have never seen live theater and would be unable to afford the experience.
"Let me begin by saying 'Thank You' for the opportunity you afforded our students at PS 84, The Lilian Weber School. This was an opportunity our students would not have otherwise had as the expense is too great for many of our families. The students enjoyed it very much. Programs such as this should continue as they open the doors for children like ours. I cannot say enough about this great opportunity we had with our students." - Mary A. Acosta, Asst. Principal, PS 84

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't donate? We understand. If you can give this a share on Facebook or Twitter to help us spread the word that would do us a world of good.

#TryToRemember

story:
Reimagining Theater For Radio

Seattle is chock full of amazing, talented and sometimes underutilized actors, writers, musicians and technicians. So, a few years ago, we decided that we wanted to create a dynamic and entertaining experience that would showcase some of these massively gifted artists - bring them all together for a single night's performance, and record it for broadcast to reach a wider audience.  What we created was Sandbox Radio Live. It combines the electricity of live theater with the resurgence of radio as a popular source of entertainment. In other words, it inspires, engages and delights with incredible live music, unpredictable and original comedy and drama scripted by local writers, poetry and adaptations of short-form classic literature, and social commentary.

And then we tossed in the entertaining spectacle of real sound effects produced and performed live on stage.  Finally, we added special guest celebrities from the community - Seattle's own rock star librarian Nancy Pearl, meteorologist Cliff Mass, renowned Chef in the Hat Thierry Rautureau, NPR contributor and cycling advocate Willie Weir, singer songwriter Lisa Koch and more - to the mix.

Not Just A One Night Stand  

Our first show generated an outpouring of enthusiasm and we realized that we had developed something that people tend to fall in love with...

“Crackling, electrifying, fresh, joyful and awesome”.  (The Stranger)

What we thought would be a just one-night stand has blossomed into full-blown love and is now ripe to move on to the next stage. Here’s what we want to do: 

  • PAY OUR CREATIVE TEAM - actors, musicians, writers
  • Add more live shows to serve our local audience
  • Expand our reach by extending our podcast through national broadcasts
  • Be able to take the show on the road 
  • Put the live shows on everyone's "What to do when you visit Seattle" list

We are motivated, dedicated and passionate about keeping this show going. But the artists who have volunteered their talents for so long enough deserve to be compensated for their amazing work and the show can’t sustain itself on ticket sales alone. Especially since it’s still a one-night-only production.

A Not-So-Indecent-Proposal

We’ve done the calculations and what we need is a sum of $25k to fund 5 shows in a full "season". The money will allow us to pay our artists, the technical team, venue and production costs, PR and marketing, rentals and equipment. 

Each episode utlitlizes the talents of:

6 writers/adapters

12-14 performers

a music director/composer

a director

a stage manager

an assistant stage manager

a production assistant

a sound engineer

a lighting engineer

a recording engineer

a post production engineer

special guest(s)

and more - that's almost 30 of Seattle's best, all working on the same show! You can rest assured that your donation will be well spent. 

Sandbox Radio Live operates under the fiscal sponsorship of Freehold Theatre Lab/Studio, a 501c(3) nonprofit organization, which means that your donation to Sandbox Radio is 100% tax deductible!

The Nitty Gritty

Because we only do each show once, ticket sales for the live event can't cover expenses, and we want to keep the podcast free and available to all. But most importantly our amazing artists have been volunteering their talents and we think its time that they got paid!

Stretch It, Baby

And if your generosity allows us to raise more than our initial goal, we plan to spend the extra cash to purchase our own sound equipment package so we can take the show to a wide variety of venues and maybe even on the road...imagine Sandbox Radio at venues like Chateau St. Michelle! 

Audio equipment includes: sound mixing board, microphones, mic stands, cables, recording interface and road boxes.

Risky Business

We’re putting it all on the line here. If we don’t meet our goal, we may not be able to keep Sandbox Radio Live alive. Thanks for your help and life-support!
story_txt:
Reimagining Theater For RadioSeattle is chock full of amazing, talented and sometimes underutilized actors, writers, musicians and technicians. So, a few years ago, we decided that we wanted to create a dynamic and entertaining experience that would showcase some of these massively gifted artists - bring them all together for a single night's performance, and record it for broadcast to reach a wider audience.  What we created was Sandbox Radio Live. It combines the electricity of live theater with the resurgence of radio as a popular source of entertainment. In other words, it inspires, engages and delights with incredible live music, unpredictable and original comedy and drama scripted by local writers, poetry and adaptations of short-form classic literature, and social commentary.
And then we tossed in the entertaining spectacle of real sound effects produced and performed live on stage.  Finally, we added special guest celebrities from the community - Seattle's own rock star librarian Nancy Pearl, meteorologist Cliff Mass, renowned Chef in the Hat Thierry Rautureau, NPR contributor and cycling advocate Willie Weir, singer songwriter Lisa Koch and more - to the mix.Not Just A One Night Stand  
Our first show generated an outpouring of enthusiasm and we realized that we had developed something that people tend to fall in love with...“Crackling, electrifying, fresh, joyful and awesome”.  (The Stranger)
What we thought would be a just one-night stand has blossomed into full-blown love and is now ripe to move on to the next stage. Here’s what we want to do: 
PAY OUR CREATIVE TEAM - actors, musicians, writers
Add more live shows to serve our local audience


Expand our reach by extending our podcast through national broadcasts


Be able to take the show on the road 


Put the live shows on everyone's "What to do when you visit Seattle" list

We are motivated, dedicated and passionate about keeping this show going. But the artists who have volunteered their talents for so long enough deserve to be compensated for their amazing work and the show can’t sustain itself on ticket sales alone. Especially since it’s still a one-night-only production.A Not-So-Indecent-Proposal
We’ve done the calculations and what we need is a sum of $25k to fund 5 shows in a full "season". The money will allow us to pay our artists, the technical team, venue and production costs, PR and marketing, rentals and equipment. Each episode utlitlizes the talents of:6 writers/adapters12-14 performersa music director/composera directora stage manageran assistant stage managera production assistanta sound engineera lighting engineera recording engineera post production engineerspecial guest(s)and more - that's almost 30 of Seattle's best, all working on the same show! You can rest assured that your donation will be well spent. 
Sandbox Radio Live operates under the fiscal sponsorship of Freehold Theatre Lab/Studio, a 501c(3) nonprofit organization, which means that your donation to Sandbox Radio is 100% tax deductible!
The Nitty Gritty
Because we only do each show once, ticket sales for the live event can't cover expenses, and we want to keep the podcast free and available to all. But most importantly our amazing artists have been volunteering their talents and we think its time that they got paid!
Stretch It, BabyAnd if your generosity allows us to raise more than our initial goal, we plan to spend the extra cash to purchase our own sound equipment package so we can take the show to a wide variety of venues and maybe even on the road...imagine Sandbox Radio at venues like Chateau St. Michelle! 
Audio equipment includes: sound mixing board, microphones, mic stands, cables, recording interface and road boxes.

Risky Business
We’re putting it all on the line here. If we don’t meet our goal, we may not be able to keep Sandbox Radio Live alive. Thanks for your help and life-support!

story:
Short Summary

Detainee is a political thriller about one woman balancing devotion to family against devotion to country.

Lindsey is a middle-aged college professor who drives a middle-aged van and lives in a middle-aged house. She's a middle-aged Mom with a middle-aged husband. She also has middle-aged problems, mostly stemming from her wayward teenage daughter, with whom she has a strained relationship.

Outside of home, Lindsey has another problem. The United States is reeling from a string of domestic bomb threats. But when the threats turn real, and the first bomb explodes, Lindsey is asked to return to her former identity. And ultimately Lindsey must choose between allegiance to country and the sanctity of her home.

Detainee is a play about a decision -- whether or not to torture a U.S. citizen.

Written by Sam Graber                                                                                                 Directed by Samantha Lee Manas

Starring: Niceto Darcey Festin, Angie Tennant*, more TBA

*appearing courtesy of Actors' Equity Association

Who Are We?

Between Us Productions is committed to bringing daring and compelling theater about controversial issues to our audiences by new and emerging artists.

We met Sam Graber when he participated in our Annual Take Ten Festival for several consecutive years. After watching many productions of his, we are finally getting to work with him with Detainee.  We are so happy to be working with and helping to support this emerging artist.

Born in March 2010, this company is the result of two long time collaborators, director, Samantha Lee Manas, and writer, Jasmine Brown. 2013 saw our first annual Take Ten Festival, a festival of ten minute plays from playwrights around the country in which the best playwrights fight to win.  Between Us Productions has produced several other productions by emerging artists including: The Fairer Sex, Uprising, Parables for the One Percent, and Behaving Badly: An Evening of One Acts.

What We Need & What You Get

In order to bring this play to life, we need funds for the theater rental, costumes, props, lighting, scenic elements, and artist fees.  Every little bit helps. Check out our perks to see what you can get!

The Impact

As the war on terrorism continues, it is now more important than ever for us to discuss the use of torture as a method for finding out information.  Is it okay if we are just torturing foreign terrorists?  What if we start torturing American citizens?   How far will we let it go?

Risks & Challenges

Discussing controversial issues can be very difficult.  Often, people just want shallow entertainment, but this is a play that is entertaining and socially challenging .  However, we find it paramount to bring these issues to light and continue the conversation on them. Taking a position can be risky and challenging, but we are up to the task.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share our campaign on social media!
  • Email our campaign to your friends!
  • Spread the word and buy a ticket!

story:
ABOUT THE SHOW

After the castle maid Willie commits a horrendous murder she is forced to flea her  home just to stay  alive. The Coward follows willies journey across the kingdom as she tries to right her wrongs all while the demon queen is in hot pursuit.

The Coward: a Madcap Fairytale is a fast-paced, absurdist comedy about the dark side of happiness. An exploration on the right every person has to not hide behind a smile and we cannot wait to share it with you.

 

ABOUT THE COMPANY

THE NATIONAL THEATRE OF MATMADIA was born of Brooklyn artists and roommates Matt Phillips and Maddy Campbell as a vehicle to bring more joy and fun to the creation of theatrical works.

Guided by a philosophy of ‘Hell Yea, I can do that’, the artists at TNTM are encouraged to be silly, stupid, and wrong with no limit on possibilities. With artists doubling as actors and designers, It is our belief that by enabling all collaborating artists to own a piece of the work then it will truly come alive; that the joy of creation takes a performance off the page and into a living, breathing entity.

 

 

WHAT WE'VE DONE SO FAR

- Applied and been accepted into FringeNYC 2016

 

- Held a month long workshop and various table reads to refine the script

 

- Wester Cooley designed the shows breathtaking makeup

 

- Held auditions

 

- Assembled a kick-ass cast (made up of %70 perfect women btw )

 

- Put together a rehearsal schedule

 

-put together this indie gogo

 

 

 

WHAT WE STILL NEED

- FringeNYC Participation Fee - $500

 

- Insurance to cover our actors during rehearsals and performances - $200

 

- Rehearsal Space - $1,000

 

- Stipends for our hardworking cast and creative team, including our Producer, Writer, Director, Marketing and Press Director, Lighting Designer, Costume Designer, Stage Manager, Photographer, and our five Actors - $1,000

 

- Postcard Printing and Mailing Services - $700

 

-  Online Marketing - $225

 

- Costumes, Makeup, Set Pieces, and Flameproofing - $800

 

While some of the funding will be raised via ticket sales, we are hoping to raise $4,500 to cover these costs, plus a little contingency (like when we need to print extras post cards because the show is so popular, or if we have to move a set piece last minute via taxi).

 

REMEMBER, NO DONATION IS TOO SMALL. EVEN $1 HELPS US OUT!

 

WHO WE ARE

 

Writer: Maddy Campbell

 

Director: Matt Phillips

 

Press and Marketing Directors: Shelby Brage & Wednesday Derrico

 

Stage Manager: Sara Minisquero

 

Makeup Desginer: Wester Cooley

 

Assistant Director: Anna Bianco

 

 

Cast:

Maddy Campbell

Matt Phillips

Anna Cain

Owen Hayden

Laurel Anderson

Brooke Turner

Wester Cooley

 

 

 

WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you're in Manhattan, Brooklyn, the Bronx, or somewhere close by... come see the show in August! That is the best support we could ask for. The proceeds we make from the show will go to cover some of the costs not covered by this campaign.

 

Not able to come see the show? A ticket to see us at FringeNYC is $18. Consider donating the cost of a ticket to the campaign.

 

If you cannot come see the show, and you cannot donate monetarily, but you would still like to help us out - please make some noise for us! A Like or a Share on Facebook or Twitter is so incredibly valuable to our fundraising efforts. Spreading the word out to even one more person that we don't know personally will help us exponentially to expand our community and reach our goal. Use the links above (you'll see them to the left of the video) to let your family and friends know about our show.

 

WHEN YOU CAN SEE IT

We're still waiting to be given our performance schedule, but there will be 5 shows between August 12th and August 28th. We'll be able to announce the venue and the show times after July 7th. So, check back here for updates!

story:
Hey there!

We’re Offside Theatre, and this October we’re mounting our inaugural production at Studio 16.

Den of Thieves by Stephen Adly Guirgis was written in 1996, but has yet to be produced in Vancouver. It’s a comedic yet meaningful play about a group of small-time criminals whose attempt to pull off the heist of their life puts them in hot water with the Italian mob.

This is a play we care deeply about and are excited to be bringing to Vancouver for the first time. After a long casting process, we have a fantastic team of actors, as well as a group of dedicated theatre professionals who are working behind the scenes to make this happen.

With theatre, every penny counts. It’s not a lucrative venture by any stretch - and we’re doing this as a labour of love, to share this story with audience members and to create opportunities for creative artists from a diverse range of backgrounds in Vancouver.

Who Is Involved:

Director: Andrea Heald  
Stage Manager: Chelsey Roy  
Set Design: John R. Taylor

Producers: Dimitri Vantis & Colette Nichol

Cast in Order of Appearance: Nathan Witte, Colette Nichol, Daniel O’Kane, Olivia Blake, Patrick Sparling, Dimitri Vantis, Greg Roger

Thank you so much for your interest in this production and for any contribution that you can make!


Yours sincerely,
Colette Nichol & Dimitri Vantis
Producers, Offside Theatre


What We Need & What You Get

We need $2000 in cold hard Canadian dollars to cover part of the following:

  • Secure a professional rehearsal space for the week leading up to the play $700
  • Pay for minimal props and set pieces, as well as minor costume necessities $400
  • Put an advert in the Georgia Straight $500
  • Purchase event insurance  $400
  • Pay royalties $700

Any extra funds we raise will go towards paying the actors and production crew a small honorarium for the hundreds of hours of work they will have put in by the end of this production.  This show is a profit share, so anything extra will be shared equally with all members of the team.

What we’re giving back is… tickets to the show, unique sponsorship opportunities for businesses, social media shout outs, art karma, and bragging rights. Thank you for supporting the arts!

“The purpose of art is washing the dust of daily life off our souls.” - Pablo Picasso

That’s what we’re here to do. And we’d love to have your support!

What if we don’t reach our funding goal?

Not a problem. We’ll just slash and burn our budget. Being in the arts means being flexible. No matter what we get, we’re going to make this show happen. 

We’ve already put up our own funds to secure the theatre and make sure the show will go on. No matter what, Den of Thieves will be coming to Studio 16 in October of 2016.

The Impact

Since we started pre-production for Den of Thieves, it has become clear that this play, and the work of Stephen Adly Guirgis means a lot to many people. 

Den of Thieves, at its core, is about people struggling to be the best versions of themselves, dealing with addiction and depression, and trying to find a way to make the best of the life they were born into.

It’s a gift to be able to work with such an excellent text. And we believe that audience members will agree when they come out to enjoy the show.

By supporting this production, you are supporting a diverse range of actors and theatre makers who are in various stages of their careers.

While the majority of the artists involved in creating this show are in the early stages of their careers, we also have some vets on the team who are jumping out of retirement to make this show happen.

We hope that this is just the first of many Offside Theatre productions, and deeply appreciate anything at all you can do to contribute.

Risks & Challenges

The biggest risk with mounting a theatrical production is that you’ll lose money. The second biggest risk is that your show will bomb. The third is that for some strange reason you just can’t get the show off the ground - disaster strikes and it doesn’t happen. How will we mitigate those risks?

  • Our production team has about 75 years of combined experience, and we can safely say that this show will happen, and it’s going to kick butt, come hell or high water.

  • The money thing...well we are willing to risk that. We might not be up for losing money at the Blackjack table, but for theatre...hell yeah!

Other Ways You Can Help

Hey, we’ve all had times when even giving away $2.50 seems like a luxury. If you aren’t able to help with money, that’s understandable. You can also support Offside Theatre in the following ways:

  • Share the campaign on Facebook, Twitter, et al

  • Save your allowance for the next three months and come to the show

  • Tell a friend about the show

  • Know a small biz who might like to advertise to an audience of intelligent theatre goers? Pass along our campaign to them.

story:
Who is Nazmo Dance Collective?

Nazmo (nah-z-moh) noun

A connection or relationship between people that cannot be expressed by words; a je ne sais quois or intangible quality that unites people by common insight, perception and understanding

Nazmo Dance Collective creates and performs original work by artistic director and founder Danielle Kipnis. Formed to promote innovative dance performance by pushing the boundaries of conventional movement, Nazmo Dance Collective has captured national attention through its interdisciplinary, collaborative, and site-specific works. The Collective uses movement to cultivate conversation regarding personal, social, and political relationships and perspectives.


What is "Matters of Facts"?

“Matters of Facts” is a dance performance and discussion event that combines movement with images, video, interviews and interactive animation to depict prisoner of war camps that existed throughout the United States during World War II. This project intends to be more than a performance – it is a multimedia dance experience. It will move audiences to do more than merely observe, immersing them in Camp Aliceville and engaging them to walk around and through the performance space as the dancers move. The work teaches, entertains and challenges modern day audiences to confront the present in light of a little-known piece of America’s past.

Why is "Matters of Facts" relevant?

The most compelling part of this history is that very few living Americans are aware that these prisoner of war camps existed on the homefront, despite the large impact they had on the surrounding communities. While quality of life for prisoners was held to a standard by Geneva Convention law, treatment within the United States exceeded that level. Captured soldiers described the camps fondly; it was a place where they were free to study, play sports, create music and theater clubs, and eat decent food. Small communities surrounding the POW camps experienced an economic boom. Civilians went to work inside the camps and prisoners worked on farms alongside American citizens, earning respectable wages from the American government. While the American Red Cross provided the POWs with money and excesses of food, American families faced war-time rations. Americans were confused about how to view the captured living in such close proximity. The German soldiers appeared to be likable members of society but they represented the enemy. In light of current debates about Guantanamo Bay and treatment of enemy soldiers, this history is especially relevant today. “Matters of Facts” presents all facets of this history through dance, sound, and projection to open up a middle ground where discussion can take place.

Through immersive dance, "Matters of Facts" beings a conversation about how we interpret our past. Our community is bombarded with highly opinionated news blurbs all day long, with little room for face to face discussion and conversation. We scroll through Facebook and Twitter news feeds, commenting virtually and superficially. “Matters of Facts” is an hour-long work that immerses the audience in one historical topic in order to open up a conversation with broad implications for our modern community.  How are we manipulated by what government and media choose to make public? Is it a problem when historical bias influences education? How should we pass down our current present for future generations?  The work does not set out to answer these questions but, rather, promote discussion by providing information in an immersive, experiential and visceral way. After experiencing this performance, audience members are invited to a post-performance discussion session with the choreographer, dancers and composer to talk about their reactions. 

Why we need your help!

"Matters of Facts" requires upwards of 150 hours of rehearsal and preparation from dancers and choreographers, a brand new score, and work with interactive body-mapping technology. The work has been developing since December 2015 and, for the final, evening length production, we are working with emerging mediums and structures in order to find new and more meaningful ways to connect to audiences. After last May's successful production of "[re]CLAIM", NDC understands the challenges that arise when producing new work. We are excited to take on those challenges again, in a new state, with new collaborators and a new audience. To make this production possible, WE NEED YOUR HELP to pay artists, fund body mapping technology and rent rehearsal and performance space. 

Your contributions will go towards the following:
4 Dancers - $900 for each dancer

  • $100 pays one dancer for one performance
  • $30 pays one dancer for one rehearsal 

1 composer - $500 to create an original score

Rehearsal space - $600 

  • $30 pays for one three-hour rehearsal

Performance Space - $1225

  • $125 pays for one hour of the performance rental

Costumes - $160

  • $40 funds one dancer's costume

Interactive Designer - $300 

Video and Photo Footage - $1000 for professional video and photos for NDC's archive and future funding 

Nazmo Dance Collective is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Nazmo Dance Collective must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate, please spread the word about Nazmo Dance Collective and "Matters of Facts". More information can be found at our website, www.DanielleKipnis.com. You can also support us by attending a performance. Please contact nazmodancecollective@gmail.com for any further questions or comments.


When and Where?

Performances:

Friday, October 28th, 7:30pm                                                                                 Saturday, October 29th, 7:30pm

All performances are at CPR (Center for Performance Research) 361 Manhattan Ave. Unit 1, Brooklyn, NY 11211

Each performance will be about one hour and followed by a discussion session. Ticket holders are invited to stay for beer, wine, and soda after each performance. Tickets can be purchased on the Indiegogo, on the CPR website or at the door.

Directions: 

By Train: Take the L to Graham Ave.

By Car: Exit 34 off of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway 


Meet the Team

Danielle Kipnis (artistic director/founder) is a New York native and founder of Nazmo Dance Collective. Danielle has performed and presented work at Lincoln Center, Jacob’s Pillow, The New World Symphony, for Art Basel Miami, in HATCH presenting series, at Harlem Repertory Theater, the West End Theater, Ailey Studios, the Rift Blackbox Theater, Little Haiti Cultural Center and Gibney Dance Center (upcoming, August 2016). Danielle’s dance films have been presented at Dance on Camera, Cucalorus and ScreenDance Miami. Her films received awards for“Best Experimental Film” at O Cinema and third prize for “Best Film” at ScreenDance Miami 2015. Danielle received her BS in Dance and English from Northwestern University where she worked with prominent Chicago artists such as Billy Seigenfeld, Molly Shanahan, Annie Beserra, and Jeff Hancock. She was invited into the Doug Varone choreographic mentorship program and has also worked with New York artists Chet Walker and Dana Moore.

Noah Pardo (Composer) is a New York City freelance composer and sound designer. He received his Bachelor’s of Music from the Steinhardt School at New York University and has since written and recorded original music for a variety of media including short films, podcasts, sketch comedy, and advertising.  In 2015 Noah scored Nazmo Dance Collective’s full length dance performance “re[CLAIM]”. He also scored NDC’s dance film, “Tagged”, featured at Dance on Camera 2015 in Lincoln Center. Noah has written original music for promotional shorts by Wondros Media in Los Angeles as well as comedy videos produced by The Huffington Post in New York City. 

Xinyao Wang (Interactive Designer) is interactive designer and creative coder originally from China, now residing in New York. She started studying Psychology and Behavioral Science and Industrial Design at Zhejiang University in 2011. During her study at Zhejiang University, she was selected to participate in and received scholarships from Singapore University of Technology and Design, Zhejiang University Exchange Programme in Singapore (2013) and JASSO at Chiba University in Japan (2014). As an industrial designer, she won the Red Dot Award, 3rd Prize in the ST Aerospace Seat Design Competition and 2nd Prize in the ZJU 4th Industrial Design Competition in 2013. After graduating from Zhejiang University, she moved to New York in 2015 where she is currently a graduate student at ITP, Tisch School of the Arts, NYU. She collaborates with choreographers, dancers and musicians to build interactive installations that use body mapping, motion capture and mix reality. 

Danielle Atkinson (Dancer) was born and raised in the United Kingdom. She received her BA in Contemporary Dance from Newcastle Upon Tyne in 2012. While in Newcastle she worked with Lo Giudice Dance,Appetite Dance, and Shaun Boyle & Artists, performing regionally and nationally in festivals and full length works. Since moving to New York, Danielle has studied at the Limon Professional Studies Program and performed with companies and artists such as Nazmo Dance Collective, Dance Visions NY, Azul Dance Theatre, Humanistic Dance, IKADA Contemporary Dance Company and The Wolfe Project.

Rebecca Gual (Dancer) is a Queens, New York native and has been groovin’ her entire life. She spent her formative years training at The Ailey School, Ballet Hispanico and Frank Sinatra School of the Arts, learning to widen her perspective of technique under the tutelage of Ani Udovicki, Elena Comendador, and Pedro Ruiz, among others. She continued her explorations at California Institute of the Arts, where she graduated with a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Dance in 2014. There she had the pleasure of working with artists such as Zoe Scofield, Julie Bour, Andre Tyson, Colin Connor and Glen Eddy. Since moving back to NYC, she has been a featured soloist with the BalaSole Dance Company and premiered work at the Queensboro Dance Festival. 

Xavier Townsend (Dancer) was born and raised in Media Pennsylvania. He started his dance training at the age of eight with a focus in Ballet and Contemporary dance. He trained at the Philadelphia Ballet School, Broadway Bound Dance Academy and Point Park University. He is a graduate of the Peridance Capezio Certificate Program. Xavier was a soloist for The Moving Beauty Series and BalaSole Dance Company in the Summer of 2015. He was a company member of Monica Hogan Danceworks and Diego Funes Dance. 

Sam Love (Aliceville POW camps Historian) is a historian and expert on Camp Aliceville. He produced a documentary and oral history about Camp Aliceville that premiered at the Aliceville Museum and Cultural Center in 1996. The documentary provides first hand accounts from prisoners, guards and Aliceville citizens about life in and around the camps. Mr. Love personally conducted many of these interviews during a 50th anniversary reunion of Camp Aliceville. Mr. Love is also a published poet.
story_txt:
Who is Nazmo Dance Collective?

Nazmo (nah-z-moh) nounA connection or relationship between people that cannot be expressed by words; a je ne sais quois or intangible quality that unites people by common insight, perception and understandingNazmo Dance Collective creates and performs original work by artistic director and founder Danielle Kipnis. Formed to promote innovative dance performance by pushing the boundaries of conventional movement, Nazmo Dance Collective has captured national attention through its interdisciplinary, collaborative, and site-specific works. The Collective uses movement to cultivate conversation regarding personal, social, and political relationships and perspectives.What is "Matters of Facts"?
“Matters
of Facts” is a dance performance and discussion event that combines movement
with images, video, interviews and interactive animation to depict prisoner of
war camps that existed throughout the United States during World War II. This project intends to be
more than a performance – it is a multimedia dance experience. It will move audiences to do more than merely observe, immersing them in Camp Aliceville and engaging them to walk around and through the performance space as the dancers move. The work teaches, entertains and challenges modern day audiences to confront the present in light of a little-known piece of America’s past.

Why is "Matters of Facts" relevant?
The most compelling part of this history is that very few living Americans are aware that these prisoner of war camps existed on the homefront, despite the large impact they had on the surrounding communities. While quality of life for prisoners was held to a standard by Geneva Convention law, treatment within the United States exceeded that level. Captured soldiers described the camps fondly; it was a place where they were free to study, play sports, create music and theater clubs, and eat decent food. Small communities surrounding the POW camps experienced an economic boom. Civilians went to work inside the camps and prisoners worked on farms alongside American citizens, earning respectable wages from the American government. While the American Red Cross provided the POWs with money and excesses of food, American families faced war-time rations. Americans were confused about how to view the captured living in such close proximity. The German soldiers appeared to be likable members of society but they represented the enemy. In light of current debates about Guantanamo Bay and treatment of enemy soldiers, this history is especially relevant today. “Matters of Facts” presents all facets of this history through dance, sound, and projection to open up a middle ground where discussion can take place.Through immersive dance, "Matters of Facts" beings a conversation about how we interpret our past. Our community is bombarded with highly opinionated news blurbs all day long, with little room for face to face discussion and conversation. We scroll through Facebook and Twitter news feeds, commenting virtually and superficially. “Matters of Facts” is an hour-long work that immerses the audience in one historical topic in order to open up a conversation with broad implications for our modern community.  How are we manipulated by what government and media choose to make public? Is it a problem when historical bias influences education? How should we pass down our current present for future generations? 
The work does not set out
to answer these questions but, rather, promote discussion by providing
information in an immersive, experiential and visceral way. After experiencing this performance, audience members are invited to a post-performance discussion session with the choreographer, dancers and composer to talk about their reactions. Why we need your help!
"Matters of Facts" requires upwards of 150 hours of rehearsal and preparation from dancers and choreographers, a brand new score, and work with interactive body-mapping technology. The work has been developing since December 2015 and, for the final, evening length production, we are working with emerging mediums and structures in order to find new and more meaningful ways to connect to audiences. After last May's successful production of "[re]CLAIM", NDC understands the challenges that arise when producing new work. We are excited to take on those challenges again, in a new state, with new collaborators and a new audience. To make this production possible, WE NEED YOUR HELP to pay artists, fund body mapping technology and rent rehearsal and performance space. Your contributions will go towards the following:
4 Dancers - $900 for each dancer




$100 pays one dancer for one performance
$30 pays one dancer for one rehearsal 

1 composer - $500 to create an original score
Rehearsal space - $600 


$30 pays for one three-hour rehearsal

Performance Space - $1225


$125 pays for one hour of the performance rental

Costumes - $160


$40 funds one dancer's costume

Interactive Designer - $300 
Video and Photo Footage - $1000 for professional video and photos for NDC's archive and future funding 
Nazmo Dance Collective is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Nazmo Dance Collective must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you cannot donate, please spread the word about Nazmo Dance Collective and "Matters of Facts". More information can be found at our website, www.DanielleKipnis.com. You can also support us by attending a performance. Please contact nazmodancecollective@gmail.com for any further questions or comments.

When and Where?
Performances:
Friday, October 28th, 7:30pm                                                                                 Saturday, October 29th, 7:30pm
All performances are at CPR (Center for Performance Research) 361 Manhattan Ave. Unit 1, Brooklyn, NY 11211
Each performance will be about one hour and followed by a discussion session. Ticket holders are invited to stay for beer, wine, and soda after each performance. Tickets can be purchased on the Indiegogo, on the CPR website or at the door.
Directions: 
By Train: Take the L to Graham Ave.
By Car: Exit 34 off of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway 

Meet the Team

Danielle Kipnis (artistic director/founder) is a New York native and founder of Nazmo Dance Collective. Danielle has performed and presented work at Lincoln Center, Jacob’s Pillow, The New World Symphony, for Art Basel Miami, in HATCH presenting series, at Harlem Repertory Theater, the West End Theater, Ailey Studios, the Rift Blackbox Theater, Little Haiti Cultural Center and Gibney Dance Center (upcoming, August 2016). Danielle’s dance films have been presented at Dance on Camera, Cucalorus and ScreenDance Miami. Her films received awards for“Best Experimental Film” at O Cinema and third prize for “Best Film” at ScreenDance Miami 2015. Danielle received her BS in Dance and English from Northwestern University where she worked with prominent Chicago artists such as Billy Seigenfeld, Molly Shanahan, Annie Beserra, and Jeff Hancock. Since moving back to NYC, she has been a featured soloist with the BalaSole Dance Company and premiered work at the Queensboro Dance Festival.

He trained at the Philadelphia Ballet School, Broadway Bound Dance Academy and Point Park University. Sam Love (Aliceville POW camps Historian) is a historian and expert on Camp Aliceville. story:
Little Fictions, Ragged Memoirs

                             Paula Josa-Jones/Performance Works

Dance, performance art, film, music!  Powerful dance theater performance that takes the audience on a journey into a visually stunning, emotionally provocative and sensual world.  

Little Fictions, Ragged Memoirs (LFRM) is a multi-media, multi-sensory dance theater project conceived, choreographed and performed by Paula Josa-Jones and her talented team of collaborators. 

LFRM is a dance triptych.  Each of the three dances integrates projection, set design, and interactive media to create stunning visual/sensory worlds that both set and disrupt a sense of place and time, creating stunning, impactful theater. Each dance raises current questions – communal and social questions about the unpredictable, unsettling ways our personal journeys intersect, and how we see, touch and change each other.

Why this is important to me and I hope to you?

For the past thirty years I have created dances and performance art.  Solos have always been an essential part of my work, but this is the first time that I am launching a full evening of solo performance.  However, this is not a one-woman show.  Each of my brilliant collaborators brings a unique and essential dimension to the work - making it a fully multi-disciplinary, group effort.  Our goal is to connect with you with new work that is powerful, transformative, and moving. 

The team:

Since 1985, I have gained a national reputation for creating bold, visually rich, emotionally charged dance theater in collaboration with artists in all disciplines.  As a company, we are committed to fostering relationships with an diverse international creative community.  This is the team for LFRM:

  • Choreography, direction, performance:  Paula Josa-Jones (and all of her cinematic alter-egos)
  • Projection Design:  Katherine Freer
  • Interactive Media Consultant:  David Tennant
  • Video:  Paula Josa-Jones & Katherine Freer
  • Photography, Video:  Pam White
  • Set Design:  Deb O & Paula Josa-Jones
  • Lighting Design:  Susan Hamburger
  • Costume Design:  Christine Joly de Lotbinniere
  •  Director:  Paola Styron

The dances:

The Traveler (terra incognita) is about the fracturing of our emotional and physical landscapes —what happens when life throws us out to the edge of the abyss. The Chaplinesque character in The Traveler is caught in a cinematic maelstrom of image, music, and movement.  How s/he navigates this world and is changed by it is the heart of the dance.  The music is by Tom Waits!!!

Mammal  explores our trans-gender, trans-species identities and our essential mammalian selves. The dance viscerally connects male and female, human and non-human at the porous borderland where they intersect and blend. 

Speak was inspired by working with my 13-year-old, profoundly autistic, non-verbal godson. It springs from questions about language and the absence of language in its usual form and my own physical research into aphasia, apraxia and synesthesia.  

In LFRM, projections are a seamless element of the choreography, another character in the space. The digital world weaves through the piece alongside the performer, transporting the audience to various settings, in and out of literal space, shifting the perception of time. Content ranges from rugged landscapes to unique structures, metaphorical imagery to a distinctly present secondary character. The figures in the video fade into and out of the changing landscapes in constant conversation with the live performer.

Why we need your help:

We need to raise $14,500 to cover our production costs which include a portion of artist fees, music licensing, and materials for projection, set, costume designs and other costs.

Your contribution will help to pay expenses for a development residency in August 2015 at The Flynn Center for the Performing Arts in Burlington, Vermont.  That is where we will all come together for the first time to put the pieces together, to experiment and push the work out to its wildest edges. 

Your pledge will also help to offset some of our production costs when we premiere the work in New York and at the Dance Complex in Cambridge, MA in early 2016!!!

On behalf of our entire creative team, I would like to thank you in advance for your support as co-producers on this exciting project.  Please check out our exciting perks !

Perks, perks, perks!

Your name in the social media news about the project?  An original Pam White print of the Venetian traveler?  A downloadable link or DVD of the performance?  A signed copy of Paula's forthcoming book, The Common Body?  Tickets to the premiere or an invitation to a rehearsal?  A film role in The Traveler?  An original commissioned painting or photograph from Pam White? 

Whatever the size of your gift, you will enjoy unique perks and our eternal appreciation.  These perks are a just a small token of our appreciation and a way that you can become an important member of our LFRM team. 

    Other ways you can help:

    If you can't make a cash donation, you can still help. 

    • Get the word out to your social media network on Facebook, Twitter, etc.. 
    • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools, and let us know what else you need to spread the word effectively.
    • Offer to help us during this development phase. Tell us what your skills are.
    • Reach out to your friends who can afford to make a financial pledge.  We actually DO believe that people want to  be asked to help.

    You are instrumental in helping us bring this project to life. Thank you again and we look forward to seeing you in the theater!

that you can become an important member of our LFRM team.  
   Other ways you can help: If you can't make a cash donation, you can still help.  

Get the word out to your social media network on Facebook, Twitter, etc..  

Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools, and let us know what else you need to spread the word effectively.

Offer to help us during this development phase. Tell us what your skills are.

Reach out to your friends who can afford to make a financial pledge.  We actually DO believe that people want to  be asked to help.

You are instrumental in helping us bring this project to life. Thank you again and we look forward to seeing you in the theater!

story:
We beseech thee! HELP US!

Calling all our little lambs! We need your help to unleash Carrie upon the city of Toronto!

This is a theatrical event 4+ years in the making! Carrie first terrified viewers in the Web Series MR. HEALTHY'S HAPPY LAND and later in the stage show of the same name that debuted at Orlando International Fringe Festival. Carrie is back with her own show and we are debuting it at The Toronto Fringe in July!

We have taken on much of the production costs ourselves, so we need a little help taking Carrie across the border! Those poor Canadians have no idea what's coming their way! 

"Each one must give as he has decided in his heart, not reluctantly or under compulsion, for God loves a cheerful giver." 2 Corinthians 9:7

In other words....give us your money! And be happy about it!

This is a flex funding campaign because we need all the help we can get but our goal is $3000. This will allow us to house our company in Toronto and ensure that they get some sustinence. I know. Starving artists, right? But they just don't do my bidding when they are hungry. This will also cover the cost of last minute set, costuming, and prop needs. 

So what do YOU get? (Besides a smug satisfaction from supporting the arts?) We have some Carrie-rific perks that should encourage your generosity. Everyone who donates will get a shout out on social media and in our Fringe program. Give us $10 and you'll get a Carrie Prayer Card with a very "special" prayer from Carrie herself! Got an extra $20 lying around? Give it to us and the playwright with write a custom haiku in your honor and send it to you with his doodles on it and stuff. (Doodles as in drawings, not number 2...) For just ten dollars more, not only will you get a Haiku but Carrie will post a video "prayer" for you on the Facebook page! Other levels/prizes include signed posters and production photos and your very own Carrie t-shirt. There are many rewards for helping others, lambs!

If we don't reach our goal, the money given will still help us get to Toronto. We may just have to let our company go a few days without food. They're young. They'll live. Props and costumes definitely come first! 

We know that most of you little lambs reading this can't make it to Toronto to see us. If we were performing this crazy little show in your town, would you buy a ticket? If you would, then throw a ten spot at us now and get your prayer card! Then follow us on social media and it will almost seem like you're right there with us. Almost. Not really but get the idea!

"A joyful heart is good medicine..." Proverbs 17:22

We would rather laugh at "those a little too right of right" than cry about some of the policies they are enacting in this country. CARRIE'S is satire. It is not meant to offend but we hope it makes you think...and LAUGH! This show, while topical and direct, is also full of joy and fun! We keep it light...and later...keep it real. This is only offensive if you don't believe that "the greatest of these is love," and if that's the case, I doubt you would be interested in supporting the arts anyway. 

As we mentioned before, Carrie was first let loose upon the world at the 2011 Orlando International Fringe Festival as a supporting character in MR. HEALTHY'S HAPPY LAND. Dave and I are life long theatre makers and arts supporters. This isn't our first rodeo. Your funds and dreams are good hands!

By supporting this project, you're not only helping us old burn outs but you will be nurturing the development of future theatre makers as two of our company members are young, impressionable theatre students. Yeah...I know. They listen to us. SCARY! This will be their first international credit and that kind of resume pad can really help shape their futures! Open your hearts, lambs! And...your wallets!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute at this time, believe me, we understand BUT you can still help us out!

  • Spread the good word, lambs! Share this with your friends! Carrie needs an army to deliver her message!
  • Like us on Facebook and invite your friends to do so!
  • Pray! Or meditate/send us all the good vibes you can!

Thank you so much for your time and support!

For just ten dollars more, not only will you get a Haiku but Carrie will post a video "prayer" for you on the Facebook page! Other levels/prizes include signed posters and production photos and your very own Carrie t-shirt. There are many rewards for helping others, lambs!
If we don't reach our goal, the money given will still help us get to Toronto. We may just have to let our company go a few days without food. They're young. They'll live. Props and costumes definitely come first! 
We know that most of you little lambs reading this can't make it to Toronto to see us. If we were performing this crazy little show in your town, would you buy a ticket? If you would, then throw a ten spot at us now and get your prayer card! Then follow us on social media and it will almost seem like you're right there with us. Almost. Not really but get the idea!   "A joyful heart is good medicine..." Proverbs 17:22
 We would rather laugh at "those a little too right of right" than cry about some of the policies they are enacting in this country. CARRIE'S is satire. It is not meant to offend but we hope it makes you think...and LAUGH! This show, while topical and direct, is also full of joy and fun! We keep it light...and later...keep it real. This is only offensive if you don't believe that "the greatest of these is love," and if that's the case, I doubt you would be interested in supporting the arts anyway. 
As we mentioned before, Carrie was first let loose upon the world at the 2011 Orlando International Fringe Festival as a supporting character in MR. HEALTHY'S HAPPY LAND. Dave and I are life long theatre makers and arts supporters. This isn't our first rodeo. Your funds and dreams are good hands!
By supporting this project, you're not only helping us old burn outs but you will be nurturing the development of future theatre makers as two of our company members are young, impressionable theatre students. Yeah...I know. They listen to us. SCARY! This will be their first international credit and that kind of resume pad can really help shape their futures! Open your hearts, lambs! And...your wallets!

    Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute at this time, believe me, we understand BUT you can still help us out!
 Spread the good word, lambs! Share this with your friends! Carrie needs an army to deliver her message!
Like us on Facebook and invite your friends to do so!
Pray! Or meditate/send us all the good vibes you can!   Thank you so much for your time and support!

story:
Empty Nesters Productions, a fiscally-sponsored project of PlayGround, is producing the world premiere of Garret Jon Groenveld's new play, "The Empty Nesters," as part of the 19th annual PlayGround Festival of New Works, scheduled to run May 18-June 14, 2015 at San Francisco's Thick House. A co-production with PlayGround and Virago Theatre Company, the premiere will be helmed by award-winning director/filmmaker Amy Glazer and feature real-life empty nesters John and Pamela Gaye Walker.

To bring this production to life, we need your help to raise $5,000 in the next thirty days. All funds will go directly to the world premiere production and contributions are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law.

story:
Short Summary


I have been a performing artist all my life and for the last 5 years I have been training specifically to be an acrobat. In 2012 I quit my job, travelled to china and spent 1 year eating, sleeping and training with the Beijing Acrobatic Troupe. At the end of last year I was accepted into the prestigious National Institute of Circus Arts (NICA) in Melbourne Australia. Without any government help, I'm faced with a $11,000 school fee.

Circus is my life! I am dedicated, highly motivated and newly inspired everyday to create art which matters, art that reaches through the superficial with ideas of humanity, connectivity and truth, and helps raise peoples consciousness to a higher vibration. I want to use my natural talents and my hard earned skills to contribute to the change that must take place within this world!


Financial Breakdown

To reach the $11,000 :

  • I have applied for a scholarship within the school
  • I will be holding fund raising circus events in Melbourne over the next 6 months
  • I will be contributing most of my own wages
  • I am reaching out to my community for support


The Impact

 
  • The skills that I will be gaining from this course will  enhance my ability to create as an artist.
  • I will have access to train on large scale apparatuses.
  • More employment opportunities will be open to me, nationally and internationally.
  • I will have a greater ability to network with other artists in my community
 

 


Other ways you can help
 If you are unable to support me finacially, but you believe in my campaign, please  share this with all your friends. And if you live in Melbourne, look out for my circus fund raising events "Darkest Before The Dawn".

story:
Short Summary

When a dragon moves into the well, crisis ensues as work grinds to a halt. Will Orphan Jack kill the dragon to save the day? If he does, he’ll marry the Princess and live an easy life. That is if he isn’t killed trying - or tossed into the moat for not trying.

Crisis demands action, and Orphan Jack rises to the occasion – only to find he prefers the company of the dragon over that of royalty. With drama, comedy, song, dance, magic, and plenty of surprises, this new musical brings to life a heart-warming story for kids of all ages.

Hi. I’m Janie Downey Maxwell, author of the historical fiction novel Gunny Malone, and the play, The Mysterious Case of the Missing Ring. Last September, I was minding my own business –working on research for the sequel to Gunny Malone in the morning, doing my corporate job during the day, and performing on stage in local community theaters at night – when this dragon, Kiran, descended on me, insisting I write his story – AND that it had to be a musical.

I tried to ignore him, but have you ever wrestled with a dragon? They’re tricky! And stubborn. Kiran wants stage time to tell his story, to show how we can change the world with a little more love, a little less judgment, and a LOT less stuff. Feeling that strange pull of the Universe, I left my corporate job at the end of December and am committed to getting this Dragon off my back and onto the stage.

Production of this piece will create:

·  Great ensemble theater done on a simple set.

·  Original song and dance numbers in a mix of styles – show tunes, blues, ballads, disco, pop, tangos, and more.

·  A cast of funny, interesting characters with great lines anyone would be proud to be part of, with an even mix of male and female characters, young and old. 

·  A musical with a universal message about the power of being kind and helping with an open heart.

So here’s where I need your help: I want to enter The Dragon's Well in the 2016 New York Music Theater Festival (NYMF). Getting into the NYMF is an incredible opportunity to stage a full production off-Broadway. Several recent shows have moved right from the NYMF to Broadway - so while a wild dream, the NYMF is a great venue to get new work exposed to NYC audiences. And who knows where it goes from there!

I am also going to submit The Dragon's Well for a Richard Rogers Award. This will help pay to get the show produced off-Broadway as part of the NYMF. 

Both submissions are due in early November.

To get The Dragon's Well ready, I wrote a shortened version of the show which we performed this past June at PortFringe here in Portland, Maine. This helped knock the rough edges off the book, and gave me the opportunity to work out three original songs.

Now the BIG work starts - editing the script, honing the script and lyrics, and finishing the score. To submit The Dragon's Well to the NYMF, I need an outstanding script - along with 75% of the score recorded. Your contribution to this campaign will help get the book perfect, and will give us the financing we need to get the score fleshed out, orchestrated, and recorded.

Getting a musical on its feet is a huge endeavor and I’m up for it. I’m an excellent writer and business woman, being both creative and organized. I love the big picture and I sweat the details. I have excellent help here in Portland to finish the score . And the Universe even sent me an editor/lyricist from NYC to help edit the book! Awesome.

The bottom line is that I have crazy love for this project and it’s going to be a great show. Check out the contribution awards to the right. And please don’t hesitate to contact me with any questions. With your help, this show will have a fairytale ending.

What We Need & What You Get

I am looking to raise $12,000 to get The Dragon's Well up and running. Your help with funding will help get the script finalized, and the score completed and recorded.

Anything we raise will help keep this show moving along. The more we raise, the better the quality of the  final recording we submit to the Festival.

The Impact

The first show I was ever in was a Christmas pageant when I was five. I remember the feeling of walking in costume through a packed audience to the small stage, feeling the energy around me, and knowing that I would do that walk again and again in my life. And I have. I’ve performed in and have helped produce dozens of shows. Each time the lights dim, the music starts, the curtains open, and the energy in the room rises, I am carried away by the magic of live theater.

Writing for the theater is a small way of giving back to an art that is so important to me and to so many others I know and love. Your support will help get a new story onto the stage for actors, crew, production artists - and audiences.

Risks & Challenges

Getting a show written, recorded, and produced is no small thing. I am working with a strong team of individuals here in Maine and in New York who will do an outstanding job of this. It’s possible that The Dragon's Well will not get into the NYMF or win a Richard Rogers award - and that’s okay too. We’ll still get this show produced and published so that acting troops around the world can perform it. It would just be nice to start on Broadway... :)

Other Ways You Can Help

I'd love it if you can help with funding for this show. AND if you can't contribute, I hope you'll help spread the word through emails and social media. Thank you, thank you, thank you! Sending great dragon love your way.
