My name is Haylee Warner, and this project is a collaborative approach to breaking down the borders of Imperialism.  It is my senior thesis project as I complete my degree at The University of the Arts.  We are approaching this huge task through our personal experiences, academic and movement research.  We are creating an interactive performance with an original sound score and elaborate hand made costuming to literally embody imperialism in its various forms (patriarchy, racism, misogyny, capitalism ect.)  This process has been long and rewarding for all of us as we learn more about each other and critically examine how we interact with the world and how we are all products of this engrained system. 

My collaborators are extremely important to me, as I could never attempt this massive project alone.  They all come from different artistic and cultural backgrounds and are listed below.
Austin - Music Business
Stephanie - Dance

Danica - Industrial Design
Maggie- Creative Writing
Nicole - Dance
Andrew - Sculpture
James- Theater
Mawiyah- Dance (Rehearsal Assistant)
The performance is free to attend!

April 2nd and 3rd at 5pm
at
The Iron Factory (118 Fontain st. Philadelphia, PA)

Presented along side this work will be two more original works by Uarts Dance Seniors! I sincerely hope you can come and enjoy all of the performance.
What We Need & What You Get
For this performance to have the most impact there are a few aspects that are critical to the presentation.  1) Having multiple perspectives informing the work.2)Ample time in the studio3) Proper costuming and props to develop images and relate to the audience.We have tried our best to cover the first two aspects.  This has shown through our committed and diverse cast, and the assistance of new people in rehearsals helping us shape and present our images.  We are asking you to help us fund these extensive, but crucial costumes and props.Each collaborator's costume will cost between 50-100 dollars.  We are buying materials, props, makeup, face prosthetics and paying for a seamstress to help us make and design each character's individual costume.I also believe that it is extremely important to pay artists for their time and dedication.  Any additional money will go to the collaborators for over a year's worth of rehearsal and research.  Finally the location is in Kensington and requires money for travel to get to and from the site.  We are hoping to have enough money to pay for the audience's travel from Center City to Kensington so the work is accessible to as many people as possible.So, rounding out the numbers...Costumes: $100x7=700Travel: $350 (4.50 per audience member + gas and tokens for each rehearsal for                                  the cast)Pay: $50x9=450=$1500For your donation you can receive various perks :)Each donation of $20 or more will receive a handwritten thank you card.Each donation of $100 or more will have the opportunity to attend one rehearsal and become a part of the process! The Impact
We are hoping to shift our audience's perspective and really get people thinking about how and why our society is controlled by these various forms of imperialism.  If we can get people thinking and learning about these harmful infrastructures, then maybe we can start to do something about them.  
Your donation brings us that much closer to the ultimate goal of education and change!

    Other Ways You Can Help We understand that not everyone has the monetary means to help us financially.  No worries! Sharing this post and spreading the word is just as important. We appreciate any and all help!

story:
For english scroll down

En utmerket gærning

Året er 1942. Teatersjef Henry Gleditsch skulle spille Doktor Relling i Villanden på Trøndelag Teater. I stedet fikk han en rolle i NS Fylkesfører Henrik Rogstads maktspill, som gav et helt annet utfall. I stedet for sitrende premierenerver, et premierekledd publikum, applaus, blomster og premierefest, ble Henry Gleditsch sammen med syv andre menn fraktet med bil til Falstad fangeleir i Ekne ved Levanger. En konsentrasjonsleir. En dødsleir.

I stedet for å avslutte forestillingen med sceneteppets fall, ble det avsluttet med en skuddsalve. To mot hodet og tre mot hjertet, i grålysningen, i Falstadskogen. Det ble altså ingen premiere på Villanden kvelden tirsdag 6. oktober 1942. Hvordan kunne en mann uten våpen være en så stor fare at de valgte å henrette akkurat han?

Som teaterkunstnere og samfunnsengasjerte har det blitt vår livsoppgave å fortelle historien til ensemblet ved Trøndelag teater med teatersjef Gleditsch i spissen. Den kommende teaterforestillingen En utmerket gærning er i skjæringspunktet mellom teaterkunsten og samfunnsengasjementet. Inspirert av den verden vi lever i, går vi tilbake i historien og feirer triumf av menneskelig samhold, medmenneskelighet og tro i møte med motstand. Vi behøver din hjelp!


Historien om Henry

En utmerket gærning forteller en episk flerdimensjonal fortelling om samhold, demokrati og ytringsfrihet. Noe ble viktigere enn teaterkunsten, men teaterkunsten ble også deres våpen. Ensemblets bånd blir testet i møter med NS og fylkesfører Rogstad. Hva var de villige til å ofre for det de trodde på? Deres reise tar dem fra etableringen av et fast teater i Trondheim til et teater underlagt strenge sensurlover.

Med hjelp fra Birger Straume (eneste gjenlevende) og etterkommere fra Henrys ensemble (Espen Skjønberg, Erik Hivju og familien Kolstad) fortelles en sjelden og personlig historie om da skuespillerne ble krigere til sceneteppets fall.


Forestillingen vil finne sted i den ærverdige Falstadgården, der Henrys historie tok slutt. Omkranset av den historiske bygningen er vi overbevist om at stemningen vil bli magisk. Våren som er i anmarsj og alt som sitter i veggene vil bidra til å gi forestillingen et ekstra historisk og mystisk preg.

Bidragene her vil bli brukt til å dekke kostnadene for å sette opp forestillingen på Falstad. Hvis, og når forestillingen gir en fortjeneste vil det bli brukt til å videreutvikle forestillingen for blant annet skole, arrangementer, festivaler og teatrene. Jo mer vi får crowdfoundet, jo større er sjansen for at historien får leve og minnene blir ivaretatt.

Midt i skogen i Ekne ved Levanger fremmer Falstadsenteret forståelse for hva som utspilte seg under andre verdenskrig. Det var her Julius Paltiel plukket opp blader med munnen, krypende på kne sammen med de andre jødene. Det var her kvinnelige fanger strikket selbuvotter av sytråd for å få tiden til å gå. Det var her Henry Gleditsch oversatte den tyske dødsdommen for de ni andre utvalgte.

Falstadsenteret, En utmerket gærning, og vi har det samme oppdraget: Å fortelle historier som utdanner og sikrer at vi aldri glemmer, og aldri gjentar, men opprettholder medmenneskelighet, ytringsfrihet og demokrati. Ved å gi i dag, vil din støtte hjelpe oss til å realisere denne forestillingen.


Tierens makt

Små ting kan ha stor innvirkning. Som det sies, "Et fjell kan flyttes, stein på stein." Selv om ingen bidrag er for store, er heller ingen for små. Faktisk er en eneste ti-kroning en meningsfull gave når vi gir sammen for et felles formål.

Kunst, i enhver form, har makt til å forvandle sinn og hjerter, og skaper muligheten for at frykt og fordommer vil slutte å vekke urettferdighet. Alle som bidrar, uavhengig av beløpet, vil ha sine navn lagt til vår virtuelle «wall of fame» på prosjektets nettsted.

Hvis et bidrag er ikke mulig på dette tidspunktet, er stemmen din fortsatt verdifull. Ta et minutt å del denne kampanjen med dine venner ved bruk av sosiale medier, og vis dem at historier som dette fortsatt er viktig.

Din deltakelse produserer ei teaterforestilling, skaper en begavelse for Falstadsenteret, og bringer oss sammen som stemmer for rettferdighet og samhold. Det er den beste av alle mulige verdener, en arv du hjelper oss å ta vare på. Denne fakkelen har vi båret, vi går nå til alle dere.

Vi håper du vil bli inspirert til å støtte og dele denne kampanjen. Sammen kan vi gjøre dette.

Fra bunnen av hjertet - takk.

Ingvild, Carl Anders og Camilla


An Excellent Madman

The year is 1942. Henry Gleditsch, the leader of the theater, was supposed to perform as Doctor Relling in «The Wild Duck» at Trøndelag Theater in Trondheim. Instead, he became a part of the intense game of power run by the county leader of the Norwegian facist party «Nasjonal Samling» Henrik Rogstad, which led to a totally different outcome. Instead of premiere nerves, a premiere dressed audience, applause, flowers and a premiere party, Henry Gleditsch and seven other men were escorted to Falstad prison camp in Ekne nearby Levanger. A consentration camp. A death camp.

Instead of ending the play with the final curtain, it ended with a volley. Two aimed for the head and three aimed for the heart, at dawn in the Falstad forest.

There was no premiere of «The Wild Duck» Tuesday evening, October 6th 1942.

How could a man with no guns make such a big threath that they decided to execute him?

As theater artists and community engaged spirits it has become our life mission to tell the story of the ensemble at Trøndelag theater with theater leader Gleditsch in charge. The upcoming theater play «An Excellent Madman» is at the intersection of theater arts and community involvement. Inspired by the world we live in, we go back in history and celebrate the triumph of human solidarity, compassion and faith in the face of resistance.

In order to make this happen, we need your help!

The story of Henry

«An Excellent Madman» tells an epic multidimensional story of solidarity, democracy and freedom of speech. Some things became more important than the theater art itself, but the theater art also became their weapon. The bond between the ensemble was tested in the many meetings with the facist party and Rogstad. How much were they willing to sacrifice for what they believed in? Their journey takes them from the establishment of a permanent theater in Trondheim to a theater run by strict laws of censure.

With help from Birger Straume (the only member still alive) and descendants of Henry's ensemble (Espen Skjønberg, Erik Hivju and the family Kolstad) tells a rare and personal story of the time when the actors were warriors until the stage curtain fell.

The play will take place in the venerable Falstad yard, where Henry's story ended. Surrounded by the historical building, we are convinced that the mood will be magical. Spring is approaching and all the stories in the walls will contribute to give the show an additional historical and mystical touch.

The contributions here will be used to defrey some of the costs of the Falstad production. If and when the production earns profits, it will be used to develope the play and the story so it can further be played at schools, events, festivals and theatres. The higher the amount crowdfounded, the higher the percentage of profit will be spent, so that the story can live on and the memories persist.

In the middle of the forest in Ekne nearby Levanger, the Falstad Centre promote an understanding of what took place during WWII. It was here that Julius Paltiel picked up leaves with his mouth, crawling on his knees along with the other jews. It was here that female prisoners knitted Selbu mittens of sewing thread to make the time pass. It was here that Henry Gleditsch translated the German death sentence to the other nine chosen.

The Falstad Centre, An Excellent Madman, and we have the same mission: To tell stories that educate and ensure that we never forget and never repeat, but maintain compassion, freedom of speech and democracy. By donating today, you will help us make this project come to life.

The power of one

Small things can have great impact. As the saying goes, "A mountain can be moved, stone by stone." While no contribution is too large, neither is any too small. Indeed, a single dollar is a meaningful gift when we give together for a common purpose.

Art, in any form, has the power to transform minds and hearts, and creates the possibility to cease injustice caused by fear and prejudice. Everyone who contributes, regardless of amount, will have their name added to our virtual "wall of fame" on the project´s website.

If a contribution is not possible at this moment, your voice is still valuable. Take a minute to share this campaign with your friends using social media, and show them that stories like this continues to matter.

Your participation produces a theater play, creates an endowment for the Falstad Centre, and brings us together as voices for justice and solidarity. It is the best of all possible worlds, a legacy you help us pass on. This torch we have carried, we will now pass it to all of you.

We hope this will inspire you to support and share this campaign. Together we can do this.

From the bottom of our hearts - thank you.

Ingvild, Carl Anders og Camilla

story:
About The Show

In February 2016, The Agency Theater Collective is very excited and proud to be producing the world premiere of The Spirit of '76. Deconstructing the (absurd) anti-suffragette play from the turn of the 20th century, The Spirit of ’76, company members Huck Poe and Andrew Gallant, along with co-director Anna Lucero, explode gender, American sexual mores, and politics.

We at The Agency strongly believe in a fresh approach to theater, whether with original scripts or new spins on classics. Agency company member Huck Poe has a developed a new play that is hilarious, confounding, and highly theatrical.

The Spirit of '76 has assembled a stellar cast and crew to bring this new work to life and opens at The Charnel House (3421 Fullerton) on Friday, February 26th.

What We Need and What You Get

Producing a play of any size is a major undertaking and even more so for a young theater company with an original script. 

Specifically, your donation will help us pay for: theater rental, costumes, set construction, lighting equipment, sound equipment and marketing costs.

Not only is your donation tax-deductible, we also have some amazing perks from our collaborators. To name a few: a year’s worth of Meisner acting classes at Green Shirt Studio, hand-drawn art, baked goodies, and original music made just-for-you, special guest honors at No Shame Theatre Chicago, handwritten thank you notes, and more. Our perks are many, carefully chosen, and made with tons of love.

The Impact

The Agency Theater Collective has been operating for nearly four years and we are proud of what we've achieved so far. In 2012 we were named runner-up "Best New Theater Company" by the Chicago Reader. The Spirit of '76 will be our fifth world premiere production following the acclaimed original works At the Center and I Wish To Apologize to the People of Illinois. In addition to our main stage shows, we have been running a weekly theatrical open mic, No Shame Theatre Chicago, for over 4 years. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We are sincerely grateful for any donation you can make to support our project. In addition to a donation, you can also help by sharing this campaign with your friends, family, and co-workers. Also, we hope you'll come see our show!

story:
Leonard Melfi's tale of two lost souls meeting in a Manhattan diner in the early 1960s returns to the NYC stage, with a twist. Birdbath premiered in New York City in 1965, at a time when experimental theatre was generating a lot of interest with mainstream audiences. We at Kitchen Table Works aim to keep the experiment going.

On a late night on Valentine's Eve, Velma and Frankie are closing up a cafeteria in Manhattan. Their conversations spark self-discoveries and unexpected confessions that cement an indelible connection.

This play will be at a site-specific venue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, NYC. We plan to open on March 11th, with a limited run. But we need your help. In order to create this piece we need to pay our artists that are collaborating on the project, and pay for materials to help make this world come alive.

Tickets are now on sale at http://birdbath.brownpapertickets.com

If you are unable to attend but would still like to support us, you can do so through our Indiegogo campaign.

A Kitchen Table Works debut. Please help us get off on the right foot so that we can keep going forward to create more pieces that don't often see the stage - Off-Off-Broadway, or any other way.

The cast includes James H. Doan* and Kiyo Takami*

*Appearing courtesy of Actors Equity Association

The production team includes: Brynn Almli (costume design), Lexie Klasing (production stage manager), Douglas Macur (video design), Kimie Nishikawa (scenic design), Milica Paranosic (sound design), and Chris Weston (lighting design).

cafeteria in Manhattan. Their conversations spark self-discoveries and 
unexpected confessions that cement an indelible connection.This play will be at a site-specific venue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, 
NYC. We plan to open on March 11th, with a limited run. But we need your
 help. In order to create this piece we need to pay our artists that are
 collaborating on the project, and pay for materials to help make this world come alive.Tickets are now on sale at http://birdbath.brownpapertickets.comIf you are unable to attend but would still like to support us, you can do so through our Indiegogo campaign.A Kitchen Table Works
 debut. Please help us get off on the right foot so that we can keep 
going forward to create more pieces that don't often see the stage - 
Off-Off-Broadway, or any other way.The cast includes James H. Doan* and Kiyo Takami**Appearing courtesy of Actors Equity AssociationThe
 production team includes: Brynn Almli (costume design), 
Lexie Klasing (production stage manager), Douglas Macur (video design), Kimie Nishikawa (scenic 
design), Milica Paranosic (sound design), and Chris Weston (lighting design).

story:
The Astonishing Adventures of All American Girl & The Scarlet Skunk is a romantic comedy about masked crime-fighters in 1948.

A new production is coming June 18th-June 24th 2016 to the Trans Theater Festival at The Brick theater in Brooklyn New York. The producers are also mounting a second production on October 3rd & 4th 2016 at Theater For The New City.

"Turn up the radio and get your decoder rings ready! “Astonishing Adventures” is a pulse-pounding tale of romance, comedy and action inspired by Golden Age comic books and radio shows. Thrill to the adventures of All American Girl and her plucky sidekick The Scarlet Skunk as they wage a two-fisted battle against injustice! Can they stand against the nefarious Doctor Mindshrinker and his deadly atomic ray gun? Will they find love on the rooftops of New York City? Find out in a tale unlike anything you have witnessed before! Brought to you by Chocolate Fluffo, the Super delicious dessert topping!"


The production team behind "Astonishing Adventures" is responsible for the post-apocalyptic comedy “That Cute Radioactive Couple” along with decades of previous theatrical productions.

Playwright Charles Battersby is also the screenwriter of The Storyteller: Fallout, an animated science fiction webseries by Shoddycast.

"Astonishing Adventures" may be a comedy about punching evildoers, but it uses humor to address serious themes that include women’s rights, “Moral Panic” and transgender issues.

WHAT WE NEED

The show is set in 1948, and has a cast of eight performers who will all need period costumes and superhero uniforms. We also have a crew who will run our lights and sound. 

Funding from our sponsors will pay for raw materials to hand craft costumes, and props. It will also provide compensation to the crew and cast, and cover costs of rehearsal space.

If our crowdfunding campaign exceeds the production costs of the show's run in June, we will use the additional funds for the run in October, and to fund readings at other events in 2016 and 2017.

WHAT YOU GET

Sponsors who can't make it to see the show live can get a downloadable audio recording in the style of a classic radio play. Sponsors can also receive autographed playbills, unique costume pieces worn onstage during the show, and can become comic book characters seen onstage during multimedia sequences.

story:
We're a Galway based Theatre Company.

Founded by two N.U.I Galway graduates and a 3 time dropout (but he's the handsome one so whatever leave me alone)

In late 2018, after combining the creative talents of B.A. in Theatre Studies, a B.A. in Creative Writing and a man who knows how to get things - Sheeny, Shane & Denis decided to make theatre. The result? JokerThief

Assembling a cast and crew of some of Galway’s finest emerging talents, JokerThief debuted "The Monday B.C." by co-founder Shane Gaffney. Shortly after this religious satire, Ireland abolished the law prohibiting blasphemy. Thus paving the way for Infidels to indulge in their heathenish whims all the way from Mizen Head to the soon to be formed Irish Border. You're welcome pagans! Receiving much acclaim from a hoard of heretics, we sold out three 3 of our 4 nights!

And now for something completely different...

 

Enter stage right “The Irish Play”

 

The play was performed in the Irish Arts Centre in New York to a six-week extended, sold-out run just over ten years ago. This year, we are excited to be collaborating with writer Tim McGillicuddy to bring his acclaimed comedy home to Irish shores.

However, given our poor life-choices - we're Blanche!

We're relying on the "kindness of strangers" since degrees in the arts aren't worth much in the way of salary. Luckily the man who knows how to get things reckons you can help! That is to say he wiped the Guinness 'tache from his lip and said “let’s do a whip around!”

But we're not simply shaking the bucket, we sing for our dinner! Instead of guilting you into making good on all those times you said you love the arts and pretended to be cultured - we're offering up some awesome perks!

Discounts on some wicked merchandise we designed, with way more to be added!* We've got t-shirts, hoodies, mugs, phone case and more, including kids, toddlers and newborn clothing!

Click Here to visit our store to see whats on offer so far!

Other perks offer a chance to own unique items that we've created or worked on during our production. There's also once in a lifetime opportunity to make a fool of the Jokers!!!

*Sheeny just has to finish that pint first!

 

What will it go toward.

In the short-term funds will go to staging and touring “The Irish Play”, by Tim McGuilicuddy. We’re slated to appear at The Nun’s Island Theatre, Galway in the first week of September as well as the Sean O’Casey Theatre, Dublin the following week. And if you’re extra generous, some other venues around the country!

Your contribution will pay for everything it takes to stage a show, from cast & crew, to set, lighting, props, costume & marketing!

It will also help get us on the road and put a roof over our heads while we travel. I checked and the Shelbourne don’t take bookings on tick :P

However big or small your contribution it goes a long long way..

 

But you're not just backing this production, you’re investing in JokerThief.

We've been scheming and we’re making it our mission to test ourselves! We will continue to work with emerging Irish talent to develop and perform original pieces! First in Ireland. Then the world.

There might come a border in Newry but all you need to climb a wall is a boost from your friends.

We’re developing a writer’s group and actor’s gym to build a community of artists who will stand on each other’s shoulders and reach heights the one cannot reach alone.  Allow us to start by standing on yours.

These may be highfalutin pipe-dreams, but we dream our eyes open! This is our passion. Help make it our life.

 

Why do we care so much??

Because in this emerging world of walls, artists will be the graffiti that stains its cobbles shouting,

“THE KING FEARS THE JESTER!”

story:
Some time ago, in the not too distant past, people in the live entertainment industry had very few ways of telling people that they exist, that they have a purpose, and that you should give a damn. One way was to rent a billboard with their face on it, and the other was to host an evening where the audience would pay to see that person sing songs and tell of their life’s adversities, fears, and personal triumphs. Both ways were often considered egotistical acts, which people grew tired of seeing… often as they were currently seeing it. 

AMBUSH CABARET is a new way of sharing unique stories of cherished members of our community, in a way that not only celebrates people, through music, comedy, and storytelling, but also does it in a way that everyone universally gives perpetual consent to. In this way, we uplift and support performing artists by sharing their innately human and relatable stories without the veil of pretense, which creates a sense of community with the audience. Plus, it’s hilariously entertaining, unexpected, and heartfelt. 

What’s not to love? There’s an element of danger watching someone perform their life story, in front of an audience, without any prior rehearsal. Literally anything could happen, and you are guaranteed to see authentic in-the-moment reactions. 

Our aim for this campaign is to ask for an investment of funds to ensure this very necessary form of live entertainment can have a healthy head start. We have proven our concept by performing two live shows for five Ambushees for completely full houses, and these successes were done with no other resources but sweat equity. 

With your contributions, we intend to, not only increase our production value which gives patrons a more fulfilling experience, but also equitably compensate our beloved cast and crew who tirelessly contribute their time and efforts in bringing each show to life. 

Having a good head start can help us look towards the future of our show. Aside from the show we have to think about maintaining upkeep costs, the expansion of our brand of entertainment into other mediums, as well as providing a possible growth into education and community outreach. The aim is not only fortitude, but growth. 

So please join us in building a strong, supportive, and extremely rewarding show which strives to enhance, entertain, and enrich, not only the live entertainment community, but a larger community who strives to love, laugh, and gain a better, more intimate understanding of the human condition. 

IN SHORT....

I'm Michael Cavinder, Creator and Artistic Director of Ambush Cabaret. Thank you for taking the time to read more about our endeavor. I’ve been a contributor and creator of theater for nearly 25 years working as an actor, director, writer, and now producer. Ambush Cabaret was conceived in 2019 during a conversation about expression of a performer's personal story and how it is nearly impossible to write a story about yourself without putting any amount of pretense in it. The only way to eliminate the filters that the artist themselves veils over their story is to omit the artist from the writing process. So that’s exactly what we did! Over the last two years, under the leadership of myself, fellow producer and director Marisa Matthews, and Musical Director Benet Braun, we and a dedicated group of actors and writers developed a show that hilariously uplifts and celebrates an artist in a way that doesn’t focus on what they’ve done to achieve recognition, but rather who they have become in order to achieve. We’ve done this with nothing but our sweat and dedication. Now we turn to you. I promise there is no other show of this nature. If you are intrigued even a little, get in on the ground floor and invest in us. Then come see what you’ve helped to create. It will not disappoint. Thank you. 

What We Need & What You Get

What we need from you is capital investment to start building a foundation for this company to grow. The quality of our show is directly affected by the quality of the talent it recruits, both on and off stage. We start with insightful and intuitive comedic writers, add in our production staff who design and build our lights, props, sound, choreography, costumes, hair and makeup, and then sprinkle in the supporting cast who bring these elements to life by singing, portraying important role models, and literally putting the star in their spotlight. We also need to utilize rehearsal spaces, advertise our events, and pay for the actual venue to perform in. The goal we set would put us in a good position to fund our first couple of shows. We don’t expect to crowdfund for every show and rest assured that your contributions will go to the production of this show directly. 

Yes, we are looking for funds but we are mainly looking for any resource that will help us build the best show possible. So if you can’t make a monetary contribution, we would gratefully accept anything you could contribute. Donate items/experiences that we can use for drawings at our shows. Have a season ticket to a baseball game, ballet, or theater? We’d love a ticket! Have a one of a kind A Christmas Story “Leg Lamp”? Kick it our way! Do you have connections to a winery? Pop that cork in our direction! 

We also still utilize sweat equity no matter what financial state we are in. Creating is hard work and if all you have to give is time, contact us and let us know how you think we could best utilize your skills. Aside from the shows we need graphic designers, social media managers, accountants, law advice, any advice really. 

At the very least please share our indiegogo page with people even if they can’t contribute either. This campaign is relatively short, so the more noise about it that’s broadcast the better our chances. 

There are tons of ways you can help and maybe you even know of another way we haven’t thought of. You are great for even reading this. Contact us with your ideas.

story:
Welcome to Raising Cain Productions, a brand new Norfolk-based theatre company, producing its debut play, "My Other Half".

Chris Sainton-Clark wrote and self-published this dark comedy thriller during the UK's first lockdown. Now that vaccinations are starting to be rolled out, and venues will hopefully be opening their doors again soon, Chris has seized the opportunity to independently produce this production using his career experience in stage management, lighting and sound design, simultaneously kickstarting his company and providing opportunities for young local creatives.

With two Norfolk venues, Sheringham Little Theatre and St George's Theatre, Great Yarmouth confirmed to house the play, the next stage is creating this production.

 

With the bulk of our budget being applied to through the Arts Council UK, we have come to indiegogo to fund the remaining budget. Paid opportunities for young local creatives is of extreme importance to us. Your donations will mean that even if we do not acquire our arts council funding for this project, we can begin to pay intial artistic fees for our creatives in addition to a profit share for them after the show has been produced. If we do not raise our full amount on indiegogo, no matter the amount, those fees will go towards our creatives. If we acquire arts council funding and earn more on our campaign than expected, then these funds will go towards taking this production to the next level and touring it nationwide.

 

Theatres and independent creatives have been hit incredibly hard by the coronavirus pandemic, especially in rural locations such as Norfolk, where support for venues is much less than bigger cities, with or without considering the pandemic. Now more than ever, it is vital that small productions find their feet and start creating work, to support their development, the development of venues and that of artists who have been struggling to find work in these tough times. Donating to this project will mean helping protect the ability for creative talents to express themselves.

 

There are risks to this production in the same way that there are risks to any, especially considering how hard gathering an audience can be at the moment. But Raising Cain Productions is fortunate to be working with venues that offer a large support network. Sheringham Little Theatre and St George's Theatre have a strong audience base that make an effort to support local small-scale theatre. Despite reduced seating size, the few productions that they have put on during the pandemic have been very popular, most notably the lockdown pantomime which was live-streamed to 210,000 school children across the country. Chris Sainton-Clark has been working alongside these productions providing lighting and sound design and operation, lending his hand to all aspects of putting on a production and is confident to bring his own creation to the stage.

Another risk is the production being postponed. Our planned date for the production is in June 2021, but this could easily not be feasible with COVID restrictions. However, our two housing venues have confirmed they want to have this production on stage and postponing it is an option.

If you can't donate to this project, following Raising Cain Productions on social media and sharing their posts will make a huge difference.

You can also purchase the script as an ebook or paperback from amazon here.

https://www.amazon.co.uk/My-Other-Half-Play-One...

story:
We The Plot

A boarding school in the German Democratic Republic, 1983. A teenage girl, abandoned by her parents, finds comfort in the relationship with her teacher, Thomas. But will her brother understand? What will happen if her friend’s illegal activities are discovered by the authorities? And who are the dark figures who visit Thomas at night?

Ideology and Hair Gel uses live music, shadow puppetry, stunning movement and fast-paced action to explore themes of misplaced power, vulnerability, homosexuality and femininity.

 

Who We Are

Waspish Theatre Company was set up in 2018 by an all-female creative team, each with a passion to give a voice to the vulnerable. Ideology and Hair Gel, written by Lizzie Corscaden and directed by Bethany-Ann Wilkinson, is Waspish Theatre's first full-length production, and examines the effects of political turmoil on the young and powerless.

The Edinburgh Fringe is the perfect place to showcase this politically-charged piece and launch Waspish Theatre into the spotlight, so that we can continue to give a voice to the unheard.

'If I be waspish, best beware my sting'- The Taming of the Shrew by William Shakespeare

 

The Cast and Crew

In April 2019, we were delighted to announce the immensely talented Cast and Crew that will be taking Ideology and Hair Gel to Edinburgh:

Cast

Heather Kirk – Elvira Tolsdorf
Will Maidment – Thomas Behler
Natasha Thurrell – Nina Hofman and understudy Elvira Tolsdorf
Sophie Max – Kat Meier
Niamh Smith – Petra Roth
Jack Pursglove – Frank Tolsdorf and Hans Fischer
Callum Pardoe – Erik Schulz, Herr Richter and Stefan
Sophie Barton – Nadine, Frau Tolsdorf and understudy Nina Hofman and Kat Meier
Laura England – Ensemble and Hanna Behler

Alison Boateng- Ensemble and Nadine 
Meg Pickup – Ensemble and understudy  and Frau Tolsdorf

Crew

Director – Bethany Wilkinson
Playwright and Dramaturg – Lizzie Corscaden

Producer- Roni Neale

Stage Manager- Lizzie Bessent 
Deputy Stage Manager – Emily Wilkinson
Composer – Sean Simmons-Barry
Publicity Design – Charlotte Deacon

 

What We Need & What You Get

While the Edinburgh Fringe is the perfect place to showcase new work, it is also expensive. Your money will go towards registration fees, accommodation, venue hire, sets, props, costumes and much much more. We believe that theatre has the power to create positive change, and even the smallest donation will go along way towards making that happen.

But there are benefits for you too! By donating, you could get anything from a poster, to free tickets for the show, or even your own personalised photobook, signed by the entire cast and crew! Check out our perks for more details.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Here at Waspish Theatre we understand that a financial contribution isn't a viable option for everyone. But you can still support this project! Why not try one of the options below?

Share this page with your friends and family!

Follow us on: Facebook - Twitter - Instagram

Pop along to one of our fundraising events (See our social media pages for details)

Come and see the show, and bring everyone you know!
story_txt: We The PlotA boarding school in the German Democratic Republic, 1983. A teenage girl, abandoned by her parents, finds comfort in the relationship with her teacher, Thomas. But will her brother understand? What will happen if her friend’s illegal activities are discovered by the authorities? And who are the dark figures who visit Thomas at night?Ideology and Hair Gel uses live music, shadow puppetry, stunning movement and fast-paced action to explore themes of misplaced power, vulnerability, homosexuality and femininity. Who We AreWaspish Theatre Company was set up in 2018 by an all-female creative team, each with a passion to give a voice to the vulnerable. Ideology and Hair Gel, written by Lizzie Corscaden and directed by Bethany-Ann Wilkinson, is Waspish Theatre's first full-length production, and examines the effects of political turmoil on the young and powerless.The Edinburgh Fringe is the perfect place to showcase this politically-charged piece and launch Waspish Theatre into the spotlight, so that we can continue to give a voice to the unheard.'If I be waspish, best beware my sting'- The Taming of the Shrew by William Shakespeare The Cast and CrewIn April 2019, we were delighted to announce the immensely talented Cast and Crew that will be taking Ideology and Hair Gel to Edinburgh:CastHeather Kirk – Elvira TolsdorfWill Maidment – Thomas BehlerNatasha Thurrell – Nina Hofman and understudy Elvira TolsdorfSophie Max – Kat MeierNiamh Smith – Petra RothJack Pursglove – Frank Tolsdorf and Hans FischerCallum Pardoe – Erik Schulz, Herr Richter and StefanSophie Barton – Nadine, Frau Tolsdorf and understudy Nina Hofman and Kat MeierLaura England – Ensemble and Hanna BehlerAlison Boateng- Ensemble and Nadine Meg Pickup – Ensemble and understudy  and Frau TolsdorfCrewDirector – Bethany WilkinsonPlaywright and Dramaturg – Lizzie CorscadenProducer- Roni NealeStage Manager- Lizzie Bessent Deputy Stage Manager – Emily WilkinsonComposer – Sean Simmons-BarryPublicity Design – Charlotte Deacon What We Need & What You GetWhile the Edinburgh Fringe is the perfect place to showcase new work, it is also expensive. Your money will go towards registration fees, accommodation, venue hire, sets, props, costumes and much much more. We believe that theatre has the power to create positive change, and even the smallest donation will go along way towards making that happen.But there are benefits for you too! By donating, you could get anything from a poster, to free tickets for the show, or even your own personalised photobook, signed by the entire cast and crew! Check out our perks for more details. Other Ways You Can HelpHere at Waspish Theatre we understand that a financial contribution isn't a viable option for everyone. But you can still support this project! Why not try one of the options below?Share this page with your friends and family!Follow us on: Facebook - Twitter - InstagramPop along to one of our fundraising events (See our social media pages for details)Come and see the show, and bring everyone you know!

story:
Short Summary

When Kyle Holmes and David Taylor Gomes sat down with their students to ask what their high school experience was like - the responses were grim:

Pressure. Anxiety. Depression. GPAs. SAT/ACT scores. Resumes. And class rank.

Holmes and Gomes were setting out to write a musical for teenagers about what mattered to them and overwhelmingly the story teenagers wanted told was the succeed-at-all-costs mentality they were enduring in our school system right now. As the conversations continued, Holmes and Gomes started noticing examples of adults sharing (and in many cases, causing) this mentality when it came to academics, and knew this was the direction their project needed to go.

After a year of discussion with students, writing, workshopping and creating, Ranked, A New Musical debuted at Granite Bay High School on April 4, just twenty-three days after Operation Varsity Blues and the college admission scandal became public. The apropos timing landed Ranked in the national spotlight, and ultimately earned rave reviews for its storytelling, music, and timeliness for teenagers and their parents alike.

The story focuses on a group of students trying to navigate a high school system in the not too distant future that values students' class rank above all else. Amidst the anxiety and competition, the story's central conflict? A student's parents paying to inflate their class rank - without their knowledge.

Holmes and Gomes did not tell the future. They listened.
And now we need everyone to listen to what our students are saying.

Ranked is a story that needs to be told nationwide.
And we need your help to make that happen.

What We Need

  1. Recording a full cast album of Ranked
    People have been asking us since the show premiered, "when can I listen to the music on Spotify/Apple Music?"  Now that we're done making major changes to the script and score, our plan is to get a group of amazingly talented actors and musicians in a recording studio and make that happen. 

    This album would not only be for your listening pleasure, but would provide us with high quality tracks from Ranked we can use to market and advertise the show to producers, publishers, and of course - new fans!

    To get in the studio and have our album mixed, we need $10,000.
     
  2. Take Ranked to New York City
    We have a lot of industry friends with a lot of industry contacts, and we want to get all of them in one room to see what Ranked is about. Our plan is to fly the creative team, some actors and some musicians to New York City for a private performance for producers, directors and publishers. Ranked, A New Musical ... on Broadway?

    Who knows. But we need to start somewhere! And if they feel as strongly about the show as many of you have, this will be a great opportunity.

    For us to buy plane tickets and secure lodging for our creative team, we need $10,000.

To record the cast album and take Ranked to New York City for a weekend, we’re asking for a total of $20,000 in contributions. 

Why This Matters

"The role of the artist is to make the revolution irresistible."  Toni Cade Bambara 

To be blunt, our modern education system is no longer sustainable.

Academic inflation has led our students to feel that anything less than a bachelor’s degree is failure. As a result, high school has become a GPA arms race – weighted courses give students the opportunity to surpass a 4.0, electives and philanthropy are simply for resumes, and College Prep Coaches provide admissions navigation to the highest bidder.

Because of this, occupations that don’t require a college degree have become stigmatized and marginalized. Woodshops, auto-shops, and skilled labor training is almost non-existent at public high schools, and “college and career centers” have really digressed into “college prep centers.” The arts have also been adversely affected by this, as students load up on as many academic classes as possible to improve their transcripts, and arts programs have fallen to the wayside.

In addition to electives, mental health has also taken a toll. Student cases of anxiety, depression and suicide have reached historic highs – all with ties to the pressure and current reality of our secondary schooling system.

Our universities have reacted to all of this. In the past ten years the average grade point average of admission has gone from a 3.5 to a 4.0. And once students arrive at their college of choice, the cost of housing, tuition and books is enough to bury them in debt (Of 2018 graduates, 69% left college with loans. An average of $29,000 in debt). Despite unemployment for recent college graduates matching all-time highs, there are millions of skilled labor vacancies in our country that remain unfilled because there aren’t enough people trained for them.

  • Historic cuts to electives.
  • Historic numbers of AP classes.
  • Historic number of college applicants.
  • Historic rates of teen depression and suicide.
  • Historic amounts of student debt.

We must make radical changes to our education system to avoid a national, systemic crisis. For our teenagers, that crisis is already here.

Ranked, A New Musical challenges audiences to question their own ideas of academic success, how it should be achieved, and what its implications are for a happy life.

Ranked In the News

  • A Dystopian High School Musical Foresaw The College Admissions Scandal
    NPR's Morning Edition

  • RANKED, A NEW MUSICAL, Premieres at the Theatre At Granite Bay
    BroadwayWorld.com

  • 'That's our play!' | College admissions scandal eerily similar to a new musical by local writers
    ABC10 News

  • Kyle Holmes And David Taylor Gomes Speak About Their Original Musical, RANKED, And Its One-Night-Only Encore CONCERT AT THE CREST THEATRE
    BroadwayWorld.com

  • Granite Bay High School’s Prophetic Musical Centers on Life as a Teen and College Admissions
    Fox40 News

  • Ranked: A New Musical To Be Performed In Concert This Weekend At The Crest
    93.1 KFBK

Check Out More From Ranked

  • "Eye on the Prize" & "Someone Always Bleeds" on Streaming Services

  • A video of "Eye on the Prize" from Theatre at Granite Bay's production of Ranked

  • Creating Ranked, A New Musical with Kyle and David

  • "Everything's Changing" from Ranked's Sitzprobe Rehearsal

In Summary

Our teenagers are in the midst of a crisis. This is their story. 

Ranked, A New Musical ignites a necessary conversation for students, parents, and anyone maintaining an antiquated idea of what it means (and costs) to be successful.

Meeting our goal of $20,000 helps us put Ranked in front of new audiences across the country to ensure these conversations happen.

story:
Hi there! 

We’re Krystina, Callie and Joe, three theatre makers who make work based on our personal experiences of the world, to bring audiences together to shed light on underrepresented stories.

We are raising money to take Krystina’s first full length play, Glitch, a show about Autism, grief, small towns and video games, to VAULT Festival this March. This semi-autobiographical show looks at what it is to be made to be an outsider and the stories we tell about those seen as different, asking- isn’t it past time we let everybody create their own stories?…

 

Who is Kelly?

Kelly’s autistic, never left her hometown because of it, and now she’s facing her Dad’s declining health. She’s frustrated, stuck, and looking for a way out - although she doesn’t realise it until it potentially arrives, in the form of a video game speedrunning contest. 

“I’m weird. Diagnosably weird. I mean, I don’t actually feel weird, but everyone tells me I am, so I must be?”

As Kelly navigates her grief, she comes to understand what her Dad has been trying to tell her all along. Other people have been writing Kelly’s story, making her a label instead of a person. Maybe it's time for that to change.

 

Why I (Krystina) wrote Glitch?

Glitch started out as a what-if; I was diagnosed with Asperger's Syndrome (a form of autism) as an adult, and I wondered what my life might have looked like if I'd been diagnosed as a child, and how I might have gotten on in the small town in which I grew up. I realised pretty quickly I was equally asking what if I'd never left my hometown; and so Sutward, with all its quirky characters, emerged pretty quickly. Around the same time, I'd become a lot more conscious of how people's perceptions of autism, particularly fuelled by fictional portrayals, differed so much from the reality I knew. I decided to try and change that!

Around the same time, I was experiencing a bereavement. It occurred to me (several months later!) that we don't talk much about the ways in which grief transforms our lives, sometimes for the better as much as for the worse. The two subject areas just became natural bedfellows in my brain from then on; Kelly's default of brutal honesty allowed me to talk honestly about the thing we're all most afraid of, and that will happen to us all.

It ought to be said that while I love video games, I am a terrible gamer and definitely not a speed runner! One thing I always did as a child, and returned to around the time of my diagnosis, was watch other people playing games like Sonic and Mario; turns out YouTube has plenty of this! Through this I discovered speed running; the high-paced, skill-driven yet somewhat solitary nature of it seemed a perfect fit for Kelly. Gaming culture has taken a bit of a hit in recent years; in making Kelly a speed runner, I wanted to celebrate the positive and fun things I'd witnessed about the community. (Meanwhile, I have been playing Breath of the Wild for over a year and am still nowhere close to finishing...)

 

The Journey so far

Krystina developed Glitch on Soho Theatre Writer's Lab 2018-19, where she found a huge amount of support because of her different point of view, not in spite of it. VAULT Festival will be its debut outing and we’re really looking forward to both getting into the Studio with it, and also to hopefully bring it to wider audiences later in the year.

It's become obvious quite quickly that even though it's explicitly about autism, and grief, those who have read it seem to have found a lot of themselves in it. This has been a delight as ultimately our belief is we're all different, but with more in common than differences, especially when it comes to autism and disability more widely. We’re really looking forward to the conversations people have around the show, and to welcoming as many as possible into a space we're carving out for new audiences.

 

What next?

Over the next month we will be finalising a performance draft of the show, designing the staging and technical elements of the show, and entering the rehearsal room. In early March the show will be performed at VAULT Festival in London, providing us with the opportunity to gather reviews, build industry connections, and allow programmers to see the show so it can have a life after these initial performances, hopefully with further performances in London, Nottingham and a run at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe.

 

How we will use the funds

The funds raised through this fundraiser will allow us to make sure the show is accessible to as many people as possible. Given the themes of the show, and the story told by the character, it would be unfair for audiences with similar stories to not be able to see this one on stage. 

Therefore funds raised would be used to cover the costs of:

- Ear defenders and tinted glasses

- Providing captioning for all performances 

- Live streaming the performances

Another important part of access is making sure everyone in the team gets paid properly, so money raised will also go towards making sure the creative team can be paid appropriately for their work and time. 

 

Thank you for reading this far and for considering donating to our show!

If you're not able to donate, but would still like to support us, please share our fundraiser and spread the word about the show

The show is on at VAULT Festival during the first two weekends of March:

March 7th - 16:30

March 8th - 15:00

March 14th - 15:00

March 15th - 18:00

You can book tickets HERE

Follow Studio Odder on Twitter

Follow Chronic Insanity on Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook

 

Team:

Writer and Performer - Krystina Nellis

Director - Callie Nestleroth

Producer - Joe Strickland

Designer - Tim Kelly

story:
Who Are You? 

The San Francisco Olympians Festival has been gaining momentum since its first year, with twenty-three plays that were commissioned by the festival having gone on to full productions: 2010’s Hermes (No Nude Men Productions, Dramaworks, Bread and Water Theatre), Juno En Victoria (Wily West Productions), and Salty Towers (Thunderbird Theater Company); 2011’s Cassiopeia (Eat Street Players), Chronus (Bread and Water Theatre), You’re Going To Bleed (DIVAFest), Io (Off The Cliff Theatre), and Pleiades (No Nude Men Productions); 2012’s Caeneus and Poseidon (Dragon Theatre) and Twins (PianoFight Productions); 2013's Take Me Home: a One-woman Odyssey (Salon San Carlos, Lucy Tafler Presents, The Edinburgh Fringe Festival) and Oenone (Redwood Day School); 2014’s Satyr Night Fever (San Francisco Theater Pub), Centaur or The Horse’s Ass (Repurposed Theatre), and The Dryad of Suburbia (PianoFight); 2015’s Cymopoleia or Wave Walker (Pear Avenue Theatre), Christian Teen Dolphin-Sex Beach Party (Awesome Theatre), and Brizo (EXIT Theatre); 2016’s Drumming With Anubis (Left Edge Theatre Company) and Ferryman (Black Sheep Theatre); 2017’s Hedetet (PianoFight) and or Horus or Supremacy (EXIT Theatre); and 2018’s Dis (Pittsburg New Works Festival). Many have also received additional readings on local and national stages, or other development or workshop opportunities, including: 2010’s Juno En Victoria (Pacific Play Company); 2011’s Joe Ryan (Impact Theatre), Pleiades (Atlantic Stage), Io (Chameleon Theatre Circle), and Selene, or Someone Like The Moon (EXIT Theatre); 2012’s Caeneus and Poseidon (Playwrights’ Center of San Francisco, City Lights Theater), and Twins (San Francisco State, Custom Made Theatre Company); 2013's Under The Gods' Golden Cleats (Dramatist Guild); 2014’s Beauty Secrets (Cutting Ball Theatre Company), Finding Medusa (Musical Café), The String’s The Thing (Inkwell Theatre); 2015’s You’ll Not Feel The Drowning and Oceanus (Custom Made Theatre Company), Ino Leucothea (Red Bull Theatre); 2016’s Ceres En Victoria (The Swedish American Hall), Lethe (Artists at Albatross Reach), Drumming With Anubis (Left Edge Theater Company), Erinyes/Eumenides (Custom Made Theatre Company) and Macaria (Custom Made Theatre Company); 2017’s Thoth (Custom Made Theatre Company); and 2018’s The Fire Wolves (Live Girls Theatre). Additionally, 2015’s You’ll Not Feel The Drowning was the recipient of the Custom Made Theatre Company’s New Development Program Workshop in 2017, 2013's Walls Of Troy was a finalist for the Stanley Drama Award, and 2014’s The String’s The Thing was the recipient of the Max K. Lerner Fellowship through Inkwell Theatre. The entire festival won "Playwriting Series Most Likely to Win a Gold Medal" from the SF Bay Guardian in 2013. EXIT Press has released a collection of five plays from Year One of the festival, Songs of Hestia, and ten plays from Year Two, Heavenly Bodies, both available for purchase on Amazon.com and at bookstores across the country. Steel Spring Stage Rights has published Ino Leucothea as part of Volume IV of Red Bull Shorts. A monologue from 2018’s Diana was included in The Best Men’s Monologues of 2019 by Smith & Kramer. Find out more at www.sfolympiansfestival.com.

Since 2010 the festival has featured the work of 125 Writers, 95 Directors, 510 Actors, and 46 Fine Artists!

Of her experience at the festival, 2018 writer Libby Emmons wrote:
"I was skeptical at first, about writing a play about a goddess, but it has opened doors in my mind, from the research phase through the writing process, in terms of what is possible on stage, what is possible if you take your feet off the ground."

This year we are excited to debut 38 new plays by 36 writers, 17 of whom will be contributing written work to the festival for the first time! The plays range from shorts to one-acts and full-lengths, and each one explores a different legend or god from the mythology of Ancient Gaul, Britain, Ireland, and the legends of King Arthur. Though exclusively local in the past, the 2019 festival includes a number of non-Bay Area writers, brought into the festival for the first time to honor the roaming spirit of the Celts! 

Why do you need so much money?

Over the years, the festival has grown and shrunk and grown again, adjusting itself to best serve the community it has come from. Though in the past we have raised as much as 12K, this year we're only looking to raise $5,000. 

$3,100 of the money we raise goes to keeping the doors of the theater open, the lights turned on and the water running- all really necessary! So, when you donate to the Festival you're actually also donating to the EXIT Theatre, the cornerstone of San Francisco's small and indie theatre scene. The rest of the money we raise is split three ways...

One third goes to marketing and materials: postcards, posters, programs, high quality printings of the work created by our fine artists, the catering for our opening night party, and of course, all the photocopies of these brand new scripts we need for the readings.

One third goes to paying our staff, which consists of an Art Director who runs the art side of the festival, a Technical Director who keeps the festival moving the nights of the Festival itself, and a Box Office Manager who runs front of house and assists our audiences with having the best possible experience they can when coming to the festival. Our Executive Director/Producer doesn't get paid and donates all his time. Our actors, directors and playwrights are paid from the box office itself each night, something we can do because our administrative staff is paid through gifts from generous benefactors like you! 

The final third of the money raised this year goes to funding an experiment we're doing for the first time: including a multi-discipline, 8 part serial that brings new theater development together with fine art creation, music, movement, and non-traditional storytelling. This work, which is being led by two of San Francisco's most exciting experimental artists, is pushing the boundaries of what the festival can do, and helps keep us a place where artists get to flex their muscles in a way they might not otherwise get to do! 

Perhaps most importantly, if we manage to raise all of our funds, we'll be able to keep our ticket price (which is only $10) low, and our comp policy generous, ensuring that the wide variety of audiences looking to experience these new works can do so affordably.

Okay, but why should I support you?

When you support this festival, you're not just supporting the 36 writers whose work will be presented this year, but also the 80+ actors we predict this festival will use, a dozen directors, and a dozen fine artists, the staff of the festival, and the theater where we work, the theater itself, the neighborhood it is located in, and the cultural life of the city that is our home. Events like the San Francisco Olympians Festival are part of what make the Bay Area a unique and inspiring place to be, a leader in the arts nationally, and a center for intellectual experiment and advancement.

Thank you for giving whatever you can give, for passing this campaign on to others you know who may want to support us, and for helping this festival continue to grow!

Find out more about the festival at www.sfolympians.com.

story_txt: Who Are You? The San Francisco Olympians Festival has been gaining momentum since its first year, with twenty-three plays that were commissioned by the festival having gone on to full productions: 2010’s Hermes (No Nude Men Productions, Dramaworks, Bread and Water Theatre), Juno En Victoria (Wily West Productions), and Salty Towers (Thunderbird Theater Company); 2011’s Cassiopeia (Eat Street Players), Chronus (Bread and Water Theatre), You’re Going To Bleed (DIVAFest), Io (Off The Cliff Theatre), and Pleiades (No Nude Men Productions); 2012’s Caeneus and Poseidon (Dragon Theatre) and Twins (PianoFight Productions); 2013's Take Me Home: a One-woman Odyssey (Salon San Carlos, Lucy Tafler Presents, The Edinburgh Fringe Festival) and Oenone (Redwood Day School); 2014’s Satyr Night Fever (San Francisco Theater Pub), Centaur or The Horse’s Ass (Repurposed Theatre), and The Dryad of Suburbia (PianoFight); 2015’s Cymopoleia or Wave Walker (Pear Avenue Theatre), Christian Teen Dolphin-Sex Beach Party (Awesome Theatre), and Brizo (EXIT Theatre); 2016’s Drumming With Anubis (Left Edge Theatre Company) and Ferryman (Black Sheep Theatre); 2017’s Hedetet (PianoFight) and or Horus or Supremacy (EXIT Theatre); and 2018’s Dis (Pittsburg New Works Festival). Many have also received additional readings on local and national stages, or other development or workshop opportunities, including: 2010’s Juno En Victoria (Pacific Play Company); 2011’s Joe Ryan (Impact Theatre), Pleiades (Atlantic Stage), Io (Chameleon Theatre Circle), and Selene, or Someone Like The Moon (EXIT Theatre); 2012’s Caeneus and Poseidon (Playwrights’ Center of San Francisco, City Lights Theater), and Twins (San Francisco State, Custom Made Theatre Company); 2013's Under The Gods' Golden Cleats (Dramatist Guild); 2014’s Beauty Secrets (Cutting Ball Theatre Company), Finding Medusa (Musical Café), The String’s The Thing (Inkwell Theatre); 2015’s You’ll Not Feel The Drowning and Oceanus (Custom Made Theatre Company), Ino Leucothea (Red Bull Theatre); 2016’s Ceres En Victoria (The Swedish American Hall), Lethe (Artists at Albatross Reach), Drumming With Anubis (Left Edge Theater Company), Erinyes/Eumenides (Custom Made Theatre Company) and Macaria (Custom Made Theatre Company); 2017’s Thoth (Custom Made Theatre Company); and 2018’s The Fire Wolves (Live Girls Theatre). Additionally, 2015’s You’ll Not Feel The Drowning was the recipient of the Custom Made Theatre Company’s New Development Program Workshop in 2017, 2013's Walls Of Troy was a finalist for the Stanley Drama Award, and 2014’s The String’s The Thing was the recipient of the Max K. Lerner Fellowship through Inkwell Theatre. The entire festival won "Playwriting Series Most Likely to Win a Gold Medal" from the SF Bay Guardian in 2013. EXIT Press has released a collection of five plays from Year One of the festival, Songs of Hestia, and ten plays from Year Two, Heavenly Bodies, both available for purchase on Amazon.com and at bookstores across the country. Steel Spring Stage Rights has published Ino Leucothea as part of Volume IV of Red Bull Shorts. A monologue from 2018’s Diana was included in The Best Men’s Monologues of 2019 by Smith & Kramer. Find out more at www.sfolympiansfestival.com.Since 2010 the festival has featured the work of 125 Writers, 95 Directors, 510 Actors, and 46 Fine Artists!Of her experience at the festival, 2018 writer Libby Emmons wrote:"I was skeptical at first, about writing a play about a goddess, but it has opened doors in my mind, from the research phase through the writing process, in terms of what is possible on stage, what is possible if you take your feet off the ground."This year we are excited to debut 38 new plays by 36 writers, 17 of whom will be contributing written work to the festival for the first time! The plays range from shorts to one-acts and full-lengths, and each one explores a different legend or god from the mythology of Ancient Gaul, Britain, Ireland, and the legends of King Arthur. Though exclusively local in the past, the 2019 festival includes a number of non-Bay Area writers, brought into the festival for the first time to honor the roaming spirit of the Celts! Why do you need so much money?Over the years, the festival has grown and shrunk and grown again, adjusting itself to best serve the community it has come from. Though in the past we have raised as much as 12K, this year we're only looking to raise $5,000. $3,100 of the money we raise goes to keeping the doors of the theater open, the lights turned on and the water running- all really necessary! So, when you donate to the Festival you're actually also donating to the EXIT Theatre, the cornerstone of San Francisco's small and indie theatre scene. The rest of the money we raise is split three ways...One third goes to marketing and materials: postcards, posters, programs, high quality printings of the work created by our fine artists, the catering for our opening night party, and of course, all the photocopies of these brand new scripts we need for the readings.One third goes to paying our staff, which consists of an Art Director who runs the art side of the festival, a Technical Director who keeps the festival moving the nights of the Festival itself, and a Box Office Manager who runs front of house and assists our audiences with having the best possible experience they can when coming to the festival. Our Executive Director/Producer doesn't get paid and donates all his time. Our actors, directors and playwrights are paid from the box office itself each night, something we can do because our administrative staff is paid through gifts from generous benefactors like you! The final third of the money raised this year goes to funding an experiment we're doing for the first time: including a multi-discipline, 8 part serial that brings new theater development together with fine art creation, music, movement, and non-traditional storytelling. This work, which is being led by two of San Francisco's most exciting experimental artists, is pushing the boundaries of what the festival can do, and helps keep us a place where artists get to flex their muscles in a way they might not otherwise get to do! Perhaps most importantly, if we manage to raise all of our funds, we'll be able to keep our ticket price (which is only $10) low, and our comp policy generous, ensuring that the wide variety of audiences looking to experience these new works can do so affordably.Okay, but why should I support you?When you support this festival, you're not just supporting the 36 writers whose work will be presented this year, but also the 80+ actors we predict this festival will use, a dozen directors, and a dozen fine artists, the staff of the festival, and the theater where we work, the theater itself, the neighborhood it is located in, and the cultural life of the city that is our home. Events like the San Francisco Olympians Festival are part of what make the Bay Area a unique and inspiring place to be, a leader in the arts nationally, and a center for intellectual experiment and advancement.Thank you for giving whatever you can give, for passing this campaign on to others you know who may want to support us, and for helping this festival continue to grow!Find out more about story:
What is SHADOW. EURYDICE SAYS?

Most people think Eurydice is a love story. Jelinek thinks otherwise. In her trademark stream-of-consciousness style, Jelinek chops, screws and tears apart the old myth, bringing feminist theory and Freud to bear on boy bands and smartphone culture. Spoken by a chorus of women of a certain age, SHADOW. EURYDICE SAYS is a jagged, vulgar last lament on the subject of love, aging, disappearing, and death.

SHADOW. EURYDICE SAYS will perform October 12–14, 2017 in the John Cullum Theatre at the American Theatre of Actors (314 W. 54th St, NY/NY) as part of the 2017 Araca Project. Get your tickets here!

 

Who are we?

Jessica Rizzo (director), Ashley Chang (producer), and Ariel Sibert (producer) are great friends who met at Yale School of Drama. They bonded over postdramatic theater, the total devastation of Magda Szabó’s “The Door," and Bikini Kill. Over the past four years, they've worked together on several projects, including SISTER SANDMAN PLEASE, REVOLT. SHE SAID. REVOLT AGAIN, and a Guerilla Girls-inspired intervention called PRAYIN WOMANTIS. Wry feminism wends its way in and out of all their collaborations and is a staple of their friendship.

 

CREATIVE TEAM

Ashley Chang / Producer
Ariel Sibert / Producer
Gitta Honegger / Translator
Jessica Rizzo / Director
Laura Petree / Assistant Director

Ilinca Tamara Todorut / Dramaturg
Elizabeth Emanuel / Stage Manager
An-Lin Dauber / Set Design

Elli Green / Lighting Design
Fan Zhang / Sound Design


CAST
Mary Round / A
Kathleen Dimmick / B
Mollie Collison / C
Susan Brickell / D
Cho Young Wiles / E
Josephine Pizzino / F
Arianne Recto / G
Azusa SHESHE Dance / H
Eloise Harris / I

 

What do we need?

For this production of SHADOW. EURYDICE SAYS, we have a fundraising goal of $5,000. Through the generosity of the Araca Project and Yale School of Drama, we have already raised 1/5th of that target amount. We need you to help get us make our goal!

﻿Your generosity helps us make the (under)world of the play–the sets, the lights, the costumes–a reality. Without you, we wouldn't have rehearsal space at the wonderful Shetler Studios in the Theater District of Manhattan, or a way to get the word out about the show, or even the rights to do the play at all. Above all else, we are dedicated to fairly compensating our entire company–the cast and the crew–for their brilliant work in these late summer months leading up to showtime. Since this is a very special one-time project, everything you give will end up in the pockets of the artists. 

See where your dollars are going when you donate to our campaign:

 

With $5,000, we will be able to achieve these goals and bring SHADOW. EURYDICE SAYS to New York City.

If you're interested in other ways of giving, we are also on the hunt for...

  • Resources for things like Concessions (wine, soda, bottled water, snacks, cups, napkins) and Box Office (ticket stubs)
  • Production Volunteers (ushers, board operators, front-of-house staff)

If you would like to talk to us about a trade or in-kind donation, we'd love to hear from you! 

Thank you so much for helping us to create SHADOW. EURYDICE SAYS. It truly means so much to us!

story:
What Are These Shows?

Greencard Wedding (greencardwedding.com)

Brooklyn 2012, where you can be whatever you want. . . until your visa expires. Inspired by a true, bittersweet love story of one band's artistic triumph via technology and music, Greencard Wedding is part rock concert, part Skype film featuring notable locations in the New York indie rock scene. This multi-media indie rock musical speaks to how we define ourselves as artists, the politics of immigration, and artist visa regulations. Performed in English and some Gaelic. Wedding cake served to all audience members. 

JODY:  Greencard Wedding is the first generative work I made. I had a band (Greencard Wedding) that had a member whose visa was canceled, which was really heartbreaking. This play is based on that experience and includes music, film and wedding cake soaked in whiskey.  Time Out has called us "talents to watch not to mention a pleasure to hear" and Broadway World has labeled our music "whiskey-soaked, heart-soaring harmonies." 

AMP (goodeproductionsnyc.com/amp)

JODY: AMP :  An electrical current. A Modern Prometheus. An investigation of Luigi Galvani, Mary Shelley and the Boston Symphony Orchestra. My new solo horror play AMP, explores scientist Luigi Galvani's discovery of animal electricity in 1790 and how it informed the creation of Mary Shelley's Frankenstein as well as the development of electroshock therapy in the 1950's.

In AMP, Mary Shelley begins the process of writing Frankenstein on stage. Mary's monologues are interwoven with film interviews of a woman who auditions for the Boston Symphony during their first historic "blind auditions" and is committed to an asylum where she undergoes electroshock therapy.

Part of the text in this show is taken directly from the writings of Mary Shelley, Percy Shelley, Lord Byron, William Godwin, Mary Wollstonecraft, Luigi Galvani and medical journals. Many of these people are voiced by actors through ghostly voice overs.

The projections used in AMP are photographs I took on location at abandoned asylums in New York and Massachuttes. Those shots were recently published here on Bored Panda

AMP was previously developed through residencies at Write Out Front, All For One Theater and New York Society Library where AMP  is the recipient of a 2017 grant for emerging female writers writing about history and literature.

 

Who Is Involved?

Greencard Wedding

Script and concept by Jody Christopherson

Co-directed by Morgan Zipf-Meister and Jody Christopherson
Starring Jody Christopherson* & Ryan McCurdy*

With David Anzuelo* & Morgan Zipf-Meister

Music by Jody Christopherson, Ryan McCurdy, Adam Swiderski, David Anzeulo

Lighting Design by Morgan Zipf-Meister

Sound and Projections Design by Martha Goode

With photography by Jody Christopherson 

and films created by the company



AMP
Written and performed by Jody Christopherson*
Directed by Isaac Byrne

Featuring the voices of Chloe Dirksen,
Finn Kilgore, Ryan McCurdy*, and Jonathan West*.

Sound and Projections Design by Martha Goode

Lighting Design by Stacey Boggs

With photography by Jody Christopherson 

and films created by the company


Both shows produced by Goode Productions
Martha Goode, Producer
Chloe Dirksen, Dialect Coach

*performing courtesy of Actors' Equity Association

 

What We Need & What You Get

Producing theater in New York is expensive. Producing independently is even harder. But it allows for the best flexibility of schedule and venue. We spent months finding the right home and time for these shows, and we're confident we've found both. Accessibility and outreach to the widest possible audience are our commitment.

With 21 performances of both shows total, our cost per performance is $2050, which means we need to sell 60 full price tickets to each performance to break even.

To think of it differently: each seat at every performance (99 seats x 21 perf.) costs approximately $20 whether or not someone is sitting there. And that's par for the course for a New York debut, one of the most expensive producing cities in the world, but one that is still at the center of the critical and artistic worlds.

Much of our budget is venue rental and overhead, but the other primary considerations include technical rentals (both shows extensively use projections and Greencard Wedding uses multiple instruments and rigs), a massive marketing and press plan to bring in audiences, and a living wage for our artists.

Our IndieGoGo amount is only a portion of the $38,000 budget these shows require, but it is a significant investment into these exciting new works and brings the per-performance cost down to a much more manageable/sellable $1,400.

The Impact

  • You are helping the curation and presentation of a new theatrical voice, which is the mission of Goode Productions.
  • You are investing in a noted track record that the full company of both shows possesses: exciting work and engaging performances.
  • You are helping to produce two shows with vastly different feels and stories which complement each other in their empathy and shared humanity.

story:
• Persona                                                                                                                                                                                         του Ίνγκμαρ Μπέργκμαν 
    από τους Elephas Tiliensis
     

Πώς είναι μια ολόκληρη προσωπικότητα; 
Όπως κι αν είναι, αντέχεται;

Ένα φουτουριστικό video clip εισάγει την πιο γραμμική κινηματογράφηση, ένας κλασσικός πίνακας μέσα σε μια υπερμοντέρνα κορνίζα, μια στρωτή ιστορία με ενοχλητικά πολλές και απειλητικά ισοδύναμες ερμηνείες, ένας ατελείωτος μονόλογος με δύο πρόσωπα, ή μήπως πολλά περισσότερα ή μήπως ούτε κι αυτό, μήπως…; Μια από τις σημαντικότερες ταινίες του εικοστού αιώνα στη σκηνή του Θεάτρου του Νέου Κόσμου. 

Η ηθοποιός Ελίζαμπεθ Βόγκλερ κατά τη διάρκεια μιας παράστασης ξαφνικά σταματάει να μιλάει και στέκει ακίνητη μπροστά στους θεατές. Έκτοτε στέκει ακίνητη και βουβή ενώπιον όλων. Από τη σκηνή του θεάτρου βρίσκεται στο λευκό, ψυχρό δωμάτιο ενός νοσοκομείου κι από εκεί στην ανησυχητική θαλπωρή μιας ιδιωτικής εστίας. Η θεραπεία της ηθοποιού αφήνεται στα λόγια της στοργικής νοσηλεύτριας, Άλμα, στα λόγια της όχι και τόσο στοργικής, στα λόγια της όχι και τόσο νοσηλεύτριας, στα όχι και τόσο αποκλειστικά δικά της λόγια. Η θεραπεία θα αφεθεί στον Λόγο κι εκείνος θα αναλάβει και τις δύο γυναίκες. Οι αρχικά διάφανοι και με ακρίβεια προσδιορισμένοι ρόλοι θα αναμειχθούν, θα αλλάξουν, θα υπονομευθούν, θα ισορροπήσουν οριακά, θα καταφύγουν σε διαδοχικές διάτρητες κρυψώνες, θα φτάσουν μια σπιθαμή από το να ανατιναχθούν· ακόμη περισσότερο θα κινδυνέψουν να γίνουν ένας.

Μια ιστορία για την μεθοριακότητα εντός, για τον πιο επικίνδυνο σωσία, εκείνον που επιλέγει μόνος του πότε θα εμφανιστεί, για το διπλό που είναι ένα, για την άλλη εκδοχή (μας), για το υποσκιασμένο μισό της προσωπικότητας· μια αναμέτρηση κυριαρχίας χωρίς αντίπαλο. Πώς είναι, άραγε, μια ολόκληρη προσωπικότητα; Κι όπως κι αν είναι, αντέχεται;

Η ομάδα Elephas Τiliensis αναμετριέται με την αισθητική και την αντανάκλαση ενός έργου τέχνης καθοριστικού για το βλέμμα που κληροδότησε ο προηγούμενος αιώνας στα μάτια μας. Πειραματίζεται με ένα «κείμενο» κλινικής ακρίβειας κι αφαίρεσης που εγκολπώνεται (συμπυκνώνεται) στην πιο απαιτητική υποκριτική, σε μια παράσταση για έναν μόνο ρόλο, που είναι δύο.
 

 

  • Persona
    Ingmar Bergman

Σκηνοθεσία, Δραματουργική επεξεργασία, Μετάφραση: Δημήτρης Αγαρτζίδης, Δέσποινα Αναστάσογλου

Δραματουργική επιμέλεια: Αλέκος Λούντζης, Αναστασία Μητροπάνου

Μουσική: Σαβίνα Γιαννάτου

Σκηνικός χώρος, Κοστούμια: Μαγδαληνή Αυγερινού

Φωτισμοί: Νίκος Βλασόπουλος

Κινησιολογική επιμέλεια: Έντι Λάμε

Προβολές: Μικαέλα Λιακατά

Κοστούμι Ηλέκτρας: Ιωάννα Πλέσσα

Βοηθός κατασκευής κοστουμιού Ηλέκτρας : Κωνσταντίνος Χαλδαίος

 

Ελίζαμπεθ Βόγκλερ: Δέσποινα Κούρτη

Αδερφή Άλμα:  Βίκυ Κατσίκα

Στο ρόλο της Ηθοποιού ακούγεται η Μαρία Κεχαγιόγλου

 

Εlephas Tiliensis

…o νάνος ελέφαντας της Τήλου.
Aπομονωμένοι για μεγάλο χρονικό διάστημα σε περιορισμένο χώρο, oι ελέφαντες της Τήλου αναγκάστηκαν να συρρικνωθούν, προκειμένου να επιβιώσουν.
Η ομάδα ιδρύθηκε το 2013. Πρώτη της εργασία ήταν η “Περσινή Αρραβωνιαστικιά” της Ζυράννας Ζατέλη. Παρουσιάστηκε την περίοδο 2013/14 & 2014/15 στο Θέατρο του Νεόυ Κόσμου, στη Θεσσαλονίκη (Θεατρικές Συναντήσεις), στα Ιωάννινα (Β’ Θεατρική Άνοιξη), στην Πάτρα και στο Ναύπλιο.
Την περίοδο 2014/15 η ομάδα συνεργάζεται με το Θέατρο Τέχνης και παρουσιάζει στο Υπόγειο μια παράσταση εμπνευσμένη από το Αλεξανδρινό Κουαρτέτο του Λόρενς Ντάρρελ “Αλεξάνδρεια -Υπάρχουν αλήθεια και ψεύδος άραγε;-“.
Την περίοδο 2015/16 παρουσίασε μια σκηνική εκδοχή του μυθιστορήματος του Βαγγέλη Ραπτόπουλου “Λούλα” στο Θέατρο του Νέου Κόσμου και στο θέατρο act στην Πάτρα.
Στο “Καλοκαίρι project” των bizoux de kant γεννήθηκε η performance “Πώς θα ‘ναι ο λυτρωτής μου;”, βασισμένη στο διήγημα του Χόρχε Λουίς Μπόρχες “Το σπίτι του Αστέριου”.
Την περίοδο 2016/17 παρουσιάζει σε συμπαραγωγή με το Θέατρο του Νέου Κόσμου μια σκηνική εκδοχή της “Persona” του Ίγκμαρ Μπέργκμαν.
Η ομάδα ιδρύθηκε από τους Δημήτρη Αγαρτζίδη και Δέσποινα Αναστάσογλου.

http://www.elephastiliensis.gr
